Here we used the following fact: $\left|x_{n}\right| \leqslant r$ in $B_{r}$ since $x_{n}^{\circ}=0$. We next estimate $K_{3}(u ; r)$ as well as $K_{4}(u ; r)$. Note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H_{0}} \\
& =\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H(0 ; 0)} \\
& =\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H\left(0 ; x_{n}\right)}+\frac{1}{H\left(0 ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H(0 ; 0)} \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d}{d \theta}\left(\frac{1}{H(\theta|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n})}\right) d \theta+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d}{d s}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(0 ; s x_{n}\right)}\right) d s \\
& =-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\partial_{1} H(\theta|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n})}{H^{2}(\theta|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n})} d \theta \cdot|\nabla u|^{2}-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\partial_{2} H\left(0 ; s x_{n}\right)}{H^{2}\left(0 ; s x_{n}\right)} d s \cdot x_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying (3.5), (3.6), (3.7) and (5.1) once again, one has

$$
\left|\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C} r \quad \text { in } B_{r}
$$

This, together with (4.15) and (4.16), gives

$$
\left|K_{3}(u ; r)\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C} r \int_{\partial B_{r}}|u||\nabla u| d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \leqslant \mathscr{C} r^{n+2}
$$

and

$$
\left|K_{4}(u ; r)\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C} \int_{\partial B_{r}} u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \leqslant \mathscr{C} r^{n+2}
$$

Collecting estimates in (5.4), (5.5), (5.7) and (5.8) together, we obtain that

$$
\left|r^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}(u ; r)\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C}
$$

This implies that the function $r \mapsto \Phi(u ; r)$ has a right limit $\Phi\left(u ; 0^{+}\right)$. We now claim that the limit is finite. It follows from the definition of $F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)$ and (5.1) that

$$
F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \leqslant \mathscr{C} r
$$

and

$$
\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \leqslant\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}+\mathscr{C}\right) r \leqslant \mathscr{C} r
$$

Thus, we obtain the boundedness of $U(u ; r)$ in terms of $H_{0}$ and $\mathscr{C}$.

$$
|U(u ; r)| \leqslant \mathcal{L}^{n}\left(B_{1}\right)\left(\mathscr{C}+\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right)
$$

Then the finiteness of $\Phi\left(u ; 0^{+}\right)$follows immediately from

$$
W(u ; r) \leqslant \mathscr{C} \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\left(\partial B_{1}\right)
$$

and $u(0)=0$ and

$$
H_{0} r^{3} W(u ; r) \rightarrow u(0) \quad \text { as } r \rightarrow 0^{+}
$$

(2). For any $0<\sigma_{1}<\sigma_{2}<+\infty$ and any vanishing sequence $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$, we integrate $\frac{\partial}{\partial r} \Phi(u ; r)$ from $r_{m} \sigma_{1}$ to $r_{m} \sigma_{2}$ and we obtain by rescaling that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}|x|^{-n-3} \frac{1}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\left(\nabla u_{m} \cdot x-\frac{3}{2} u_{m}\right)^{2} d x \\
& =\Phi\left(u ; r_{m} \sigma_{2}\right)-\Phi\left(u ; r_{m} \sigma_{1}\right) \\
& -\int_{r_{m} \sigma_{1}}^{r_{m} \sigma_{2}} r^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) d r
\end{aligned}
$$

where $H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right):=H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)$. Thus, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}|x|^{-n-3} \frac{1}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\left(\nabla u_{m} \cdot x-\frac{3}{2} u_{m}\right)^{2} d x \\
& \leqslant \Phi\left(u ; r_{m} \sigma_{2}\right)-\Phi\left(u ; r_{m} \sigma_{1}\right) \\
& +\int_{r_{m} \sigma_{1}}^{r_{m} \sigma_{2}} r^{-n-2}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)\right| d r
\end{aligned}
$$

Passing to the limit as $m \rightarrow+\infty$, we infer from the existence and finiteness of $\Phi\left(u ; 0^{+}\right)$and (5.9) that the right hand side of equation (5.10) tends to 0 . Moreover, it follows from the fact $\lim _{m} H_{m}=H_{0}$ that $H_{m} \geqslant e H_{0}$ for $m$ large enough and $e>0$ universal. Thus, (5.10) implies that

$$
\lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty} \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}|x|^{-n-3}\left(\nabla u_{m} \cdot x-\frac{3}{2} u_{m}\right)^{2} d x=0
$$

This, together with the convex of the function $v \mapsto \int|x|^{-n-3}\left(\nabla v \cdot x-\frac{3}{2} v\right)^{2} d x$ and the lower semicontinuity under weak convergence in $W^{1,2}$, implies $\nabla u_{0}-$ $\frac{3}{2} u_{0}=0$ a.e. in $B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}$. This is equivalent to say that $u_{0}$ is a homogeneous function of degree $3 / 2$.
(3). Let $u_{m}$ be defined in (5.2). We first claim that $\frac{1}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}:=$ $\frac{1}{H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)}$ converges to $\frac{1}{H_{0}}$ strongly in $L_{\text {loc }}^{2}$. To this end, it suffices to prove that

$$
I_{m}:=\int_{B_{1}}\left|\frac{1}{H_{m}}-\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right|^{2} d x \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } m \rightarrow+\infty
$$

Since $\lim _{m} H_{m}=H(0 ; 0)$, we have that $\left\|H_{m}-H_{0}\right\|_{L^{\infty}\left(B_{1}\right)} \leqslant \mathscr{C}$ uniformly for $m$ large enough. Thanks to (5.6), one has

$$
I_{m} \leqslant \mathscr{C} \int_{B_{1}}\left|\frac{1}{H_{m}\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right| d x
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leqslant \mathscr{C} r_{m} \int_{B_{1}}\left(\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\left|\partial_{1} H_{m}\left(|\theta \nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)\right|}{H_{m}^{2}\left(|\theta \nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \theta\right) \cdot\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} d x \\
& +\mathscr{C} r_{m} \int_{B_{1}}\left(\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\left|\partial_{2} H_{m}\left(0 ; s x_{n}\right)\right|}{H_{m}^{2}\left(0 ; s x_{n}\right)} d s\right) \cdot x_{n} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\partial_{1} H_{m}(\theta|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}):=\partial_{1} H\left(\theta r_{m}|\nabla u|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)
$$

and

$$
\partial_{2} H_{m}\left(0 ; s x_{n}\right):=\partial_{2} H\left(0 ; s r_{m} x_{n}\right)
$$

It then follows from Lemma 3.1 that $\partial_{1} H_{m}$ and $\partial_{2} H_{m}$ are bounded by $\left\|H_{m}\right\|_{L^{\infty}}$, and thus bounded by a uniform constant $\mathscr{C}$ that is independent of $m$. Therefore, we show that

$$
I_{m} \leqslant \mathscr{C} r_{m} \int_{B_{1}}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}+x_{n}\right) d x \leqslant \mathscr{C} r_{m}
$$

where we applied the growth condition (5.1) in the last inequality. Passing to the limit as $m \rightarrow+\infty$ gives (5.11). We now infer from the weak $L^{2}$ convergence of $\nabla u_{m}$ and the strong $L^{2}$ convergence of $H_{m}$ that

$$
0=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\nabla u_{m} \nabla \eta}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x \rightarrow \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\nabla u_{0} \nabla \eta}{H_{0}} d x
$$

for each $\eta \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. This gives that $u_{0}$ is harmonic in $\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}$ in the distributional sense. Additionally, since $u_{m}$ converges to $u_{0}$ strongly in $L_{\text {loc }}^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$, it is easy to show that

$$
\lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{u_{m} \nabla u_{m} \nabla \eta}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{u_{0} \nabla u_{0} \nabla \eta}{H_{0}} d x
$$

Consequently, for every test function $\eta \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& o(1)+\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{0}} \eta d x \\
& =\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} \eta d x \\
& =-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{u_{m} \nabla u_{m} \nabla \eta}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x \\
& \rightarrow-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{u_{0} \nabla u_{0} \nabla \eta}{H_{0}} d x \\
& =\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \frac{\left|\nabla u_{0}\right|^{2}}{H_{0}} \eta d x
\end{aligned}
$$

This gives the strong $W^{1,2}$ convergence of $u_{m}$.

Remark 5.3. If we define

$$
\widetilde{\Phi}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right):=\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-\sum_{i=1}^{4} \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; t\right) d t
$$

where $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ and $K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right), i=1, \ldots, 4$ are defined in (4.11), (4.13), (4.14) and (4.16), respectively. Moreover, since the limit $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$exists and $K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ are integrable functions defined in $\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$, we can deduce from (5.12) that

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial r} \widetilde{\Phi}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \geqslant 0 \quad \text { and } \quad \widetilde{\Phi}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)
$$

5.1. Weighted densities. The first statement in Lemma 5.1 indicates that the limit $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$exists and is finite for $x^{\circ} \in \partial\{u>0\}$ with $x_{n}^{\circ}=0$. Moreover, thanks to the second statement of Lemma 5.1, every blow-up $u_{0}$ is a homogeneous function of degree $3 / 2$. In what follows, we compute explicit values of $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$for each stagnation point $x^{\circ} \in \Omega$ with $x_{n}^{\circ}=0$. It should be noted that these values provide a explicit geometric description of the solutions at the stagnation points. We now state the main result of this subsection.

Lemma 5.4. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4) and suppose that $u$ satisfies (5.1). Then the following holds.
(1) Let $x^{\circ} \in \Omega$ be such that $x_{n}^{\circ}=0$. Then

$$
\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=\frac{1}{H_{0}} \lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} x_{n}^{+} \chi_{\{u>0\}} d x
$$

and in particular $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right) \in[0, \infty)$. Moreover, $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=0$ implies that $u_{0}=0$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ for each blow-up $u_{0}$ of Lemma 5.1.
(2) The function $x \mapsto \Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$is upper semi-continuous in $\left\{x_{n}=0\right\}$.
(3) Assume that $u_{m}$ given in (5.2) is a sequence of variational solutions of (3.4) in a domain $\Omega_{m}$, where

$$
\Omega_{1} \subset \Omega_{2} \subset \cdots \subset \Omega_{m} \subset \Omega_{m+1} \subset \ldots \quad \text { and } \cup_{m=1}^{\infty} \Omega_{m}=\mathbb{R}^{n}
$$

such that $u_{m}$ converges strongly to $u_{0}$ in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and that $\chi_{m}:=$ $\chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}}$ converges weakly in $L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ to $\chi_{0}$. Then $u_{0} \in C_{\mathrm{loc}}^{0}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \cap$ $C_{\mathrm{loc}}^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} \cap\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}\right), u_{0} \geqslant 0$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n}, u_{0} \equiv 0$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n} \cap\left\{x_{n} \leqslant 0\right\}$, and $u_{0}$ satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left(\left|\nabla u_{0}\right|^{2} \operatorname{div} \phi-2 \nabla u_{0} D \phi \nabla u_{0}\right) d x \\
& +\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left(x_{n} \chi_{0} \operatorname{div} \phi+\chi_{0} \phi_{n}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

for each $\phi=\left(\phi_{1}, \ldots, \phi_{n}\right) \in C_{0}^{1}\left(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. Furthermore, we have that $u_{0}$ satisfies the monotonicity formula (4.11), but with $F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \equiv$ $\frac{1}{H_{0}}|\nabla u|^{2}, \lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \equiv \frac{1}{H_{0}} x_{n}$, and $\chi_{\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}}$ replaced by $\chi_{0}$.

Finally, for each $x^{\circ} \in \Omega$, and all instances of $\chi_{\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}}$ replaced by $\chi_{0}$,

$$
\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u_{0} ; 0^{+}\right) \geqslant \lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty} \Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u_{m} ; 0^{+}\right)
$$

Proof. (1) Without loss of generality we assume that $x^{\circ}=0$, let $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$ be a vanishing sequence as $m \rightarrow+\infty$ and let $u_{m}$ be the blow up sequence defined in (5.2). We denote $\Phi(u ; r):=\Phi(0, u ; r)$ for simplicity. It follows from (4.11) and a direct calculation that for any $r>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(u ; r r_{m}\right) & =r^{-n-1} J_{H_{m}}\left(u_{m} ; B_{r}\right)-\frac{3}{2} W\left(u_{m} ; r\right) \\
& -\left(r r_{m}\right)^{-n-1} K_{1}\left(u ; r r_{m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, as in (4.20), $J_{H_{m}}\left(u_{m} ; B_{r}\right)$ is defined by

$$
J_{H_{m}}\left(u_{m} ; B_{r}\right):=\int_{B_{r}} \frac{\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}+\frac{x_{n}}{H_{0}} \chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}} d x
$$

where $H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right):=H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)$. Thanks to (5.4), we have that $\left|K_{1}\left(u ; r r_{m}\right)\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C}\left(r r_{m}\right)^{n+2}$. Therefore,

$$
\lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty}\left(r r_{m}\right)^{-n-1} K_{1}\left(u ; r r_{m}\right)=0, \quad \forall r>0
$$

On the other hand, since $u_{m}, H_{m}$ converges to $u_{0}, H_{0}$ strongly in $W^{1,2}$ and $L^{2}$, respectively, we infer from (5.15), $u_{0}$ is harmonic in $\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}$, and $u_{0} \equiv 0$ on $\left\{x_{n} \leqslant 0\right\}$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =\lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty}\left[r^{-n-1} J_{H_{m}}\left(u_{m} ; B_{r}\right)-\frac{3}{2} W\left(u_{m} ; r\right)-\Phi\left(u ; r r_{m}\right)\right] \\
& =r^{-n-1} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{\partial B_{r}} u_{0}\left(\nabla u_{0} \cdot \nu-\frac{3}{2} \frac{u_{0}}{r}\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +\lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty}\left[\frac{1}{H_{0}} r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n} \chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}} d x-\Phi\left(u ; r r_{m}\right)\right] \\
& =\lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty} \frac{1}{H_{0}} r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n} \chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}} d x-\Phi\left(u ; 0^{+}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the fact that $u_{0} \in W_{\text {loc }}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ is a homogeneous function of degree $3 / 2$ and that $\Phi\left(u ; 0^{+}\right)$exists and is finite in the last equality. This proves (1).

(2). For each $\delta>0$ we obtain from (5.12) and (5.13), as well as the fact that $\lim _{x \rightarrow x^{\circ}} \Phi(x, u ; r)=\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$, that

$$
\Phi\left(x, u ; 0^{+}\right) \leqslant \Phi(x, u ; r)+\mathscr{C} r \leqslant \Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)+\frac{\delta}{2} \leqslant \Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)+\delta
$$

This proves (2).
(3). Let $u_{m}$ be the blow-up sequence defined in equation (5.2), then (5.1) implies for each vanishing sequence $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$we can find a subsequence (still denoted $r_{m}$ ) along which $u_{m} \rightarrow u_{0}$ locally uniformly and weakly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ to some function $u_{0}: \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow[0,+\infty), u_{0} \equiv 0$ on $\left\{x_{n} \leqslant 0\right\}$. It follows from Lemma 5.1 that $u_{m}$ converges to $u_{0}$ strongly in $W_{\text {loc }}^{1,3}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and that $u_{0}$ is harmonic in $\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}$. Thus $u_{0}$ is continuous in $\Omega$ and $C^{2}$ in the positive set $\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}$. Let now $\phi \in C_{0}^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n} ; \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and set $\phi_{m}(x):=\phi\left(\frac{x}{r_{m}}\right)$. It follows from (4.3) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =\int_{\Omega_{m}}\left[\frac{\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}+\frac{x_{n}}{H_{0}} \chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}}\right] \operatorname{div} \phi d x \\
& -\int_{\Omega_{m}} \frac{2 \nabla u_{m} D \phi \nabla u_{m}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}+\frac{\phi_{n}(x)}{H_{0}} \chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}} d x \\
& +\sum_{i=1}^{2} \mathcal{I}_{i}\left(u_{m} ; r_{m}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Omega_{m}:=\left\{x: r_{m} x \in \Omega\right\}, H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right):=H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{I}_{1}\left(u_{m} ; r_{m}\right) & =r_{m}^{-1} \int_{\Omega_{m}}\left[\int_{0}^{r_{m} x_{n}} \frac{\partial}{\partial \tau}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)}\right) \tau d \tau\right] \operatorname{div} \phi \chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}} d x \\
& -r_{m}^{-1} \int_{\Omega_{m}}\left[\int_{0}^{r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial \tau}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)}\right) \tau d \tau\right] \operatorname{div} \phi d x
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{I}_{2}\left(u_{m} ; r_{m}\right) & =\int_{\Omega_{m}}\left[\int_{0}^{r_{m} x_{n}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{n}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)}\right) d \tau\right] \chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}} \phi_{n} d x \\
& -\int_{\Omega_{m}}\left[\int_{0}^{r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial \tau}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)}\right) d \tau\right] \phi_{n} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from a similar argument as in (5.4) and (5.5) that

$$
\left|\mathcal{I}_{i}\left(u_{m} ; r_{m}\right)\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C} r_{m}
$$

for $i=1$, 2. Thanks to the strong convergence of $u_{m}$ and $H_{m}$, we infer from (5.16) that

$$
0=\frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left(\left(\left|\nabla u_{0}\right|^{2}+x_{n} \chi_{0}\right) \operatorname{div} \phi-2 \nabla u_{0} D \phi \nabla u_{0}+\chi_{0} \phi_{n}\right) d x
$$

This proves (5.14). Let us now define

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u_{0} ; r\right) & =\frac{r^{-n-1}}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)}\left(\left|\nabla u_{0}\right|^{2}+x_{n} \chi_{0}\right) d x \\
& -\frac{3}{2} \frac{r^{-n-2}}{H_{0}} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} u_{0}^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from our argument that $u_{0}$ is a variational solution in the sense of Definition 3.1 in [60]. The rest of the proof follows along a similar argument as in $[60$, Lemma $4.2(\mathrm{v})]$, so we omit it.
5.2. Possible singular profiles in two dimensions. We can now compute all the possible profiles of the free surface at the stagnation points with the aid of Lemma 5.1 and Lemma 5.4.

Proposition 5.5 (two-dimensional case). Let $n=2$ and let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4), and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant \mathscr{C} x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Let $x^{\circ} \in \Omega$ be such that $u\left(x^{\circ}\right)=0$ and $x_{2}^{\circ}=0$, and suppose that

$$
r^{-3 / 2} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \sqrt{x_{2}}\left|\nabla \chi_{\{u>0\}}\right| d x \leqslant \mathscr{C}_{0}
$$

for all $r>0$ such that $B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right) \subset \subset \Omega$. Then the following statements hold:
(1) $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right) \in\left\{0, \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}, \frac{2}{3 H_{0}}\right\}$.
(2) If $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}$, then

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}} \rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} R^{3 / 2} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2}\left(\min \left\{\max \left\{\theta, \frac{\pi}{6}\right\}: \frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and locally uniformly in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$.
(3) If $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=0$, then

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}} \rightarrow 0 \text { as } r \rightarrow 0^{+}
$$

strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and locally uniformly in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$.
Proof. Let $u_{m}$ be the blow-up sequence defined in equation (5.2), where $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$as $m \rightarrow+\infty$, then $u_{m}$ converges to a blow-up $u_{0}$ strongly in $W_{\text {loc }}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. Moreover,equation (5.14) implies that $u_{0}$ is a homogeneous solution to

$$
0=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\left(\left|\nabla u_{0}\right|^{2} \operatorname{div} \phi-2 \nabla u_{0} D \phi \nabla u_{0}\right) d x+\int_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}\left(x_{2} \chi_{0}+\chi_{0} \phi_{2}\right) d x
$$

for any $\phi \in C_{0}^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$. Here, $\chi_{0}$ is the strong $L^{1}$ limit of $\chi_{m}:=\chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}}$ along a subsequence. Then the argument reduces to [60, Proposition 4.7,

Boundary case]. To conclude the proof, we calculate explicitly the weighted density $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$at $x^{\circ}$. In the case $u_{0} \neq 0$, we have that $\chi_{m} \rightarrow \chi_{0}=$ $\chi_{\{x: \pi / 6<\theta<5 \pi / 6\}}$, and therefore, we deduce from Lemma 5.4 (1) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right) & =\frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{1}} x_{2}^{+} \chi_{\{x: \pi / 6<\theta<5 \pi / 6\}} d x \\
& =\frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{0}^{1} \rho^{2} d \rho \int_{\pi / 6}^{5 \pi / 6} \sin \theta d \theta \\
& =\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the case when $u_{0}=0$, there are two possibilities, either $\chi_{m} \rightarrow \chi_{0}=0$ or $\chi_{m} \rightarrow \chi_{0}=\chi_{\{x: 0<\theta<\pi\}}$. This gives that either $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=0$ or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right) & =\frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{1}} x_{2}^{+} \chi_{\{x: 0<\theta<\pi\}} d x \\
& =\frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{0}^{1} \rho^{2} d \rho \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta d \theta \\
& =\frac{2}{3 H_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 5.6. Based on the results we have deduced in Proposition 5.5, we classify each stagnation point into two categories. We refer to the first category as degenerate stagnation points, while the second category consists of non-degenerate stagnation points. The precise definition will be given in Definition 6.1. Roughly speaking, a stagnation point is considered degenerate if the blow-up $u_{0}$ at this point is identically zero. Otherwise, we regard it as a non-degenerate stagnation point.

Remark 5.7. It should be noted that at the degenerate stagnation points $x^{\circ}$, the analysis above suggests that $u_{m}(x):=\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r_{m} x\right)}{r_{m}^{\alpha}} \rightarrow u_{0} \neq 0$ for some $\alpha>\frac{3}{2}$. However, it is a priori unknown whether $u$ decays like a polynomial at $x^{\circ}$ or not. Therefore, there is a possibility that $u_{m} \rightarrow 0$ for any $\alpha>0$. In the forthcoming section, we will give an explicit answer that even at the degeneracy stagnation points, the solution $u$ decays like a polynomial.

Remark 5.8. In the rest of the paper, we will refer to the value $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}$ as the Stokes density, the value 0 as the trivial density, and the value $\frac{2}{3 H_{0}}$ as the horizontal flat density.

# 6. NON-DEGENERATE STAGNATION POINTS 

In this section, we will analyze the scenario when $u_{0}$ is not identically zero. We first collect all the stagnation points together and we define

Definition 6.1 (Stagnation points). Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4). We call

$$
S^{u}:=\left\{x=\left(x^{\prime}, x_{n}\right) \in \Omega \cap \partial\left\{u>0\right\}: x_{n}=0\right\}
$$

the set of stagnation points.
For each stagnation point, we define
Definition 6.2 (Non-degenerate and degenerate stagnation points). Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4). We say that a stagnation point $x^{\circ} \in S^{u}$ is a non-degenerate stagnation point if

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}} \rightarrow u_{0} \not \equiv 0 \quad \text { as } r \rightarrow 0^{+}
$$

along a subsequence. Otherwise, we call $x^{\circ}$ a degenerate stagnation point.
Remark 6.3. By our definition, if $x^{\circ}$ is a non-degenerate stagnation point, then thanks to Proposition 5.5, $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}$. Otherwise, if $x^{\circ}$ is a degenerate stagnation point, then either $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=0$ or $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=$ $\frac{2}{3 H_{0}}$. But one should note that in both cases we have $u_{0} \equiv 0$, this is referred to as the "degenerate" case.
6.1. Structure of the non-degenerate stagnation points. In this subsection, with the aid of Proposition 5.5, we first study the non-degenerate stagnation points. In this subsection, with the aid of Proposition 5.5, we first study the non-degenerate stagnation points. Our first result is the following measure estimates at the non-degenerate stagnation points.

Lemma 6.4. Let $n=2$ and let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4), and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant \Subset x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Let $x^{\circ} \in \Omega$ be such that $u\left(x^{\circ}\right)=0$ and $x_{2}^{\circ}=0$, and suppose that

$$
r^{-3 / 2} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \sqrt{x_{2}}\left|\nabla \chi_{\{u>0\}}\right| d x \leqslant \Subset_{0}
$$

for all $r>0$ such that $B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right) \subset \subset \Omega$. Let $x^{\circ} \in S^{u}$ be a non-degenerate stagnation point, then
(1). The "weighted density" $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$has the Stokes density $\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}$ and

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}} \rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} R^{3 / 2} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2}\left(\min \left\{\max \left\{\theta, \frac{\pi}{6}\right\}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and locally uniformly on $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, where $x=$ $(R \cos \theta, R \sin \theta)$.

(2). There exists a $e_{0}>0$ so that

$$
\frac{\int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} x_{2}^{+} \chi_{\{u>0\}} d x}{r \mathcal{L}^{2}\left(B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)\right)} \geqslant e_{0}
$$

Moreover,

$$
\mathcal{L}^{2}\left(B_{1} \cap\left(\left\{x: u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)>0\right\} \triangle\left\{x: \frac{\pi}{6}<\theta<\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}\right)\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, and for each $\delta>0$,

$$
r^{-3 / 2} L u\left(\left(x^{\circ}+B_{r}\right) \backslash\left\{x: \min \left\{\left|\theta-\frac{\pi}{6}\right|,\left|\theta-\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right|\right\}<\delta\right\}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$. Recall that Lu is a nonnegative Radon measure.
Proof. Assume that $x^{\circ}=0$, the value of $\Phi\left(u ; 0^{+}\right)$and the uniqueness of the blow-up follows directly from the second statement Proposition 5.5, and (1) is proved. It follows from (5.12) and (5.13) in Remark 5.3 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
0<\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}} & =\widetilde{\Phi}\left(u ; 0^{+}\right) \\
& \leqslant \widetilde{\Phi}(u ; 1) \\
& =U(u ; 1)-\frac{3}{2} W(u ; 1)+\int_{0}^{1} \sum_{i=1}^{4}\left|t^{-n-2} K_{i}(u ; t)\right| d t
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used (4.11) in the last equality. Thanks to (5.4), (5.5), (5.7) and (5.8), one has $\sum_{i=1}^{4} t^{-n-2}\left|K_{i}(u ; t)\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C}$. Thus, by setting $e_{0}:=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}$, we deduce from $W(u ; 1) \geqslant 0$, the growth condition (5.1) that

$$
e_{0} \leqslant\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}+\mathscr{C}\right) \int_{B_{1}} x_{2}^{+} \chi_{\{u>0\}} d x
$$

Then (6.2) follows by rescaling.
For any arbitrary vanishing sequence $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$, let us consider $u_{m}$ given in (5.2). Define

$$
u_{0}(R, \theta)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} R^{3 / 2} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2}\left(\min \left\{\max \left\{\theta, \frac{\pi}{6}\right\}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)
$$

We may infer from the proof of Proposition 5.5 that $\chi_{m}:=\chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}}$ converges to $\chi_{\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}}$ strongly in $L^{1}\left(B_{1}\right)$ along a subsequence. Since this is true for all sequences $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$, we have

$$
\chi_{\left\{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)>0\right\}} \rightarrow \chi_{\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}} \quad \text { strongly in } L^{1}\left(B_{1}\right) \quad \text { as } r \rightarrow 0^{+}
$$

which is exactly the measure estimate (6.3). The strong $L^{2}$ convergence of $H_{m}$ to $H_{0}$ and the weak $L^{2}$ convergence of $\nabla u_{m}$ to $\nabla u_{0}$ immediately imply

the weak convergence of the sequence of non-negative Radon measures $L u_{m}$ to $\frac{\Delta u_{0}}{H_{0}}$. In other words, for each $\eta \in C_{0}^{1}\left(B_{1}\right)$,

$$
\int_{B_{1}} \eta d L u_{m}=\int_{B_{1}} \frac{\nabla u_{m} \nabla \eta}{H_{m}\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x \rightarrow \int_{B_{1}} \frac{\nabla u_{0} \nabla \eta}{H_{0}} d x=\int_{B_{1}} \eta d\left(\frac{\Delta u_{0}}{H_{0}}\right)
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$. Note that $u_{0}$ is harmonic in

$$
B_{1} \backslash\left\{x: \min \left\{\left|\theta-\frac{\pi}{6}\right|,\left|\theta-\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right|\right\}<\frac{\delta}{2}\right\}
$$

and this implies that

$$
\left(\frac{\Delta u_{0}}{H_{0}}\right)\left(B_{1} \backslash\left\{x: \min \left\{\left|\theta-\frac{\pi}{6}\right|,\left|\theta-\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right|\right\}<\frac{\delta}{2}\right\}\right)=0
$$

Thus,

$$
\left(L u_{m}\right)\left(B_{1} \backslash\left\{x: \min \left\{\left|\theta-\frac{\pi}{6}\right|,\left|\theta-\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right|\right\}<\frac{\delta}{2}\right\}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

as $m \rightarrow+\infty$. The second measure estimate (6.4) follows.
We now prove that all non-degenerate stagnation points are isolated.
Proposition 6.5 (Isolatedness of the non-degenerate stagnation points). Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4) for $n=2$ and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant \mathscr{C} x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

and that

$$
r^{-3 / 2} \int_{B_{r}(y)} \sqrt{x_{2}} \mid \nabla \chi_{\{u>0\}} \mid d x \leqslant \mathscr{C}_{0}
$$

for all $B_{r}(y) \subset \subset \Omega$ with $y_{2}=0$. Suppose that $x^{\circ} \in S^{u}$ is a non-degenerate stagnation point. Then in some open neighborhood, $x^{\circ}$ is the only nondegenerate stagnation point.

Proof. Suppose towards a contradiction that there exists a sequence $x^{m}$ of non-degenerate points converging to $x^{\circ}$, with $x^{m} \neq x^{\circ}$ for all $m$. Let $r_{m}:=$ $\left|x^{m}-x^{\circ}\right|$, and assume without loss of generality that $\left(x^{m}-x^{\circ}\right) / r_{m} \rightarrow z \in$ $\{(-1,0),(1,0)\}$. Let us consider the blow-up sequence $u_{m}$ defined in (5.2). Since $x^{m}$ is a non-degenerate stagnation point for $u$, we have that the point $z$ is a non-degenerate stagnation point for $u_{m}$, and therefore Lemma 6.4 implies that

$$
\Phi\left(z, u_{m} ; 0^{+}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}
$$

By Lemma 5.1 (2) and Proposition 5.5 (2), the sequence $u_{m}$ converges strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ to the homogeneous solution

$$
u_{0}(R, \theta)=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} R^{3 / 2} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2}\left(\min \left\{\max \left\{\theta, \frac{\pi}{6}\right\}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)
$$

while $\chi_{m}:=\chi_{\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}}$ converges to $\chi_{\left\{u_{0}>0\right\}}$ strongly in $L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. It follows from Lemma 5.4 (2) that

$$
\Phi\left(z, u_{0} ; 0^{+}\right) \geqslant \limsup _{m \rightarrow+\infty} \Phi\left(z, u_{m} ; 0^{+}\right)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{3 H_{0}}
$$

This contradicts the fact that $\Phi\left(z, u_{0} ; 0^{+}\right)=0$.
Remark 6.6. Let us remark that
(1) In two dimensions the set of stagnation points $S^{u}$ can be decomposed into a countable set of "Stokes points" with asymptotics as in Lemma 6.4, accumulating (if at all) only at "degenerate stagnation points", and a set of "degenerate stagnation points" will be analyzed in the following section.
(2) In higher dimensions $n \geqslant 3$, one can follow a similar argument as in [61, Lemma 5.7] to conclude that the Hausdorff dimension of the set of all non-degenerate stagnation points is less than or equal to $n-2$.

# 7. Degenerate Stagnation Points 

In this section, we analyze the degenerate stagnation points, in which case the blow-up $u_{0}$ is identically zero in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. In general, this implies that the decay rate of the solution is strictly higher than $\left|x-x^{\circ}\right|^{3 / 2}$ near each degenerate stagnation points $x^{\circ}$ (cf. (6.1)). The analysis of the degenerate stagnation points in this section exclude the possibility of cusp-type and horizontal flat-type singularities, thus proving the Stokes conjecture.
7.1. Cusp points. Let $n=2$ and let $x^{\circ} \in S^{u}$ be a degenerate stagnation point. In this subsection, we focus on those stagnation points with the trivial density $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=0$. These points are termed as degenerate stagnation points with trivial density because both blow-up $u_{0}$ and density $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$ are zero.

Definition 7.1. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4). We define the set of stagnation point with trivial density as

$$
C^{u}:=\left\{x^{\circ} \in S^{u}: \Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=0\right\}
$$

It follows from Proposition 5.5 (3) that if $x^{\circ} \in C^{u}$, then along a subsequence, $u_{m} \rightarrow 0$ as $m \rightarrow+\infty$. In this specific case, we show that (in Lemma 7.2) if the solution $u$ satisfies the growth condition $|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{+}$ near the stagnation points, then $C^{u}=\varnothing$.

Lemma 7.2. Let $u$ be a subsonic weak solution of (3.4) for $n=2$ and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Then $\Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=0$ implies that $u \equiv 0$ in some open two-dimensional ball containing $x^{\circ}$.

Proof. The idea of the proof is borrowed from [60, Lemma 4.4], which mainly depends on the inequality $L u \geqslant \sqrt{x_{2}} \mathcal{H}^{1} \ll \partial_{\text {red } $\{u>0\}$ and the fact that one can locate a non-empty portion of $\partial_{\text {red }}\{u>0\}$. Suppose towards a contradiction that $x^{\circ} \in \partial\{u>0\}$, and let us take a blow-up sequence

$$
u_{m}(x):=\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r_{m} x\right)}{r_{m}^{3 / 2}}
$$

converging weakly in $W_{\text {loc }}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ to a blow up limit $u_{0}$. Lemma 5.1 (2) gives that $u_{0} \equiv 0$ in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. Consequently, the non-negative Radon measure satisfies

$$
L u_{m}\left(B_{2}\right) \rightarrow\left(\frac{\Delta u_{0}}{H_{0}}\right)\left(B_{2}\right)=0
$$

and

$$
L u_{m} \geqslant \sqrt{x_{2}} \mathcal{H}^{1} \ll \partial_{\mathrm{red}}\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}=\int_{B_{2} \cap \partial_{\mathrm{red}}\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}} \sqrt{x_{2}} d S
$$

On the other hand, there is at least one connected component $V_{m}$ of $\left\{u_{m}>\right.$ $0\}$ touching the origin and containing, by the maximum principle, a point $x^{m} \in \partial A$, where $A=(-1,1) \times(0,1)$. If

$$
\max \left\{x_{2}: x \in V_{m} \cap \partial A\right\} \nrightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } m \rightarrow+\infty
$$

we immediately reach a contradiction to (7.1) and (7.2). On the other hand, if

$$
\max \left\{x_{2}: x \in V_{m} \cap \partial A\right\} \rightarrow 0
$$

then

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =L u_{m}\left(V_{m} \cap A\right) \\
& =\int_{\partial_{\mathrm{red}} V_{m} \cap A} \frac{\nabla u_{m} \cdot \nu}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)} d S+\int_{V_{m} \cap \partial A} \frac{\nabla u_{m} \cdot \nu}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)} d S
\end{aligned}
$$

Here $H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right):=H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{2}\right)$. Given that $u$ is a subsonic weak solution, we infer from (4.5) that $\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}=x_{2}$, and therefore

$$
H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)=H_{m}\left(x_{2} ; x_{2}\right)=H_{0} \quad \text { on } \quad \partial_{\operatorname{red}} V_{m} \cap A
$$

It follows from the growth condition $\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}$ and $t \mapsto H(t ; \cdot)$ is a strictly decreasing function that $H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right) \geqslant H_{m}\left(x_{2} ; x_{2}\right)=H_{0}$ on $V_{m} \cap \partial A$. Consequently,

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & \leqslant-\int_{\partial_{\operatorname{red}} V_{m} \cap A} \frac{\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)} d S+\int_{V_{m} \cap \partial A} \frac{\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)} d S \\
& \leqslant-\int_{\partial_{\operatorname{red}} V_{m} \cap A} \sqrt{x_{2}} d S+\int_{V_{m} \cap \partial A} \sqrt{x_{2}} d S
\end{aligned}
$$

However, this contradicts to the fact that $\int_{V_{m} \cap \partial A} \sqrt{x_{2}} d S$ is the unique minimizer of $\int_{\partial D} \sqrt{x_{2}} d S$ with respect to all open sets $D$ with $D=V_{m}$ on $\partial A$. Thus $V_{m}$ cannot touch the origin, a contradiction.

Remark 7.3. In general, we call the growth condition $|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+}$the strong Bernstein estimates. Compared to (5.1), it should be noted that the constant $C=1$ helps us to obtain the sharp order $H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \geqslant H_{0}$.
7.2. Horizontal flatness points. In this subsection, let us consider those stagnation points $x^{\circ} \in S^{u}$ whose density takes the horizontal flat density $\frac{2}{3 H_{0}}$. Formally, we define
Definition 7.4. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4). We define the set of stagnation point with horizontal flat density as

$$
\Sigma^{u}:=\left\{x^{\circ} \in S^{u}: \Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=\frac{2}{3 H_{0}}\right\}
$$

Remark 7.5. It should be noted that as a consequence of the upper semicontinuity of the function $x \mapsto \Phi\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$, the set $\Sigma^{u}$ is closed.

Lemma 7.6. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4), let $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$, and let $\delta_{0}$ be defined in (3.8). Assume that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

(1) For each $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$, we have the inequality

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}-\frac{3}{2} \geqslant \frac{\frac{r}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& +\frac{e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ is defined by

$$
e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)=r^{n+2} \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; t\right) d t+r K_{1}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)
$$

and $K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ for $i=1, \ldots, 4$ are defined in (4.13), (4.14), (4.15) and (4.16).
(2) There exists some $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ sufficiently small so that

$$
\frac{r}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \geqslant 0
$$

for all $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$.
(3) The function

$$
r \mapsto W\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \quad \text { is non-decreasing in }\left(0, r_{0}\right)
$$

for some $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ sufficiently small. Here, $W\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ is defined in (4.10).

Proof. (1). Assume without loss of generality that $x^{\circ}=0 \in \Sigma^{u}$. Let $\widetilde{\Phi}(u ; r):=\widetilde{\Phi}(0, u ; r)$ be given as in (5.12), then it follows from Remark 5.3 that $\widetilde{\Phi}(u ; r)$ is a non-decreasing function for $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\Phi}(u ; r) & \geqslant \widetilde{\Phi}\left(u ; 0^{+}\right) \\
& =\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left[\Phi(u ; r)-\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}(u ; t) d t\right] \\
& =r^{-n-1} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$ in the last equality and $r \mapsto r^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}(u ; r)$ is integrable on $\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$. This gives the inequality

$$
\begin{aligned}
& r \int_{B_{r}} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x-\frac{3}{2} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{\partial B_{r}} u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& \geqslant \frac{r}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then (7.4) follows by dividing the inequality (7.6) by the nonnegative term $\frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{\partial B_{r}} u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}$ on both sides of (7.6).
(2). Recalling (4.17), we deduce from the nonnegativity of $\frac{\partial}{\partial \tau}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right)$ and the growth condition (7.3) that

$$
\int_{0}^{|\nabla u|^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial \tau}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right) \tau d \tau \leqslant \int_{0}^{x_{n}} \frac{\partial}{\partial \tau}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right) \tau d \tau
$$

Therefore, we may deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
r^{-n-1}\left|K_{1}(u ; r)\right| & \leqslant r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}}\left|\int_{0}^{x_{n}} \frac{\partial}{\partial \tau}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right) \tau d \tau\right|\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x \\
& \leqslant \mathscr{C} r^{-n} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used (5.3) in the second inequality. The estimates (7.7) gives

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\left|r^{-n-1} K_{1}(u ; r)\right|}{r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}=0
$$

Moreover (7.7) implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} K_{1}(u ; t) d t & \leqslant \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2}\left|K_{1}(u ; t)\right| d t \\
& \leqslant \mathscr{C} \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-1} \int_{B_{t}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x d t
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (4.22) that

$$
K_{2}(u ; r):=\int_{B_{r}}\left(\mathcal{K}^{-}(x)+\mathcal{K}^{+}(x)\right) d x
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{K}^{-}(x):=\int_{0}^{|\nabla u|^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{n}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right) x_{n} d \tau\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) \leqslant 0
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}^{+}(x) & :=\left(\int_{0}^{|\nabla u|^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{n}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right) x_{n} d \tau\right. \\
& \left.-\int_{0}^{x_{n}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{n}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right) x_{n} d \tau\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \\
& \geqslant 0
\end{aligned}
$$

We can then deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
K_{2}(u ; r) & =\int_{B_{r} \cap\left\{\mathcal{K}^{+}>-\mathcal{K}^{-}\right\}}\left(\mathcal{K}^{-}+\mathcal{K}^{+}\right) d x+\int_{B_{r} \cap\left\{\mathcal{K}^{+} \leqslant-\mathcal{K}^{-}\right\}}\left(\mathcal{K}^{-}+\mathcal{K}^{+}\right) d x \\
& \geqslant \int_{B_{r}}\left[\int_{0}^{|\nabla u|^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_{n}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(\tau ; x_{n}\right)}\right) x_{n} d \tau\right]\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from a similar calculation as in (5.5) that

$$
\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} K_{2}(u ; t) d t \geqslant-\mathscr{C} \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-1} \int_{B_{t}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x d t
$$

Let us now define

$$
\Pi(r):=\int_{0}^{r} \tau^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x d \tau
$$

It follows that $\Pi(r) \geqslant 0$ for all $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right), \Pi(0)=0$ and a direct calculation that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Pi^{\prime \prime}(r) & =r^{-n-2}\left[(n+1) \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+} \chi_{\{u>0\}} d x-r \int_{\partial B_{r}} x_{n}^{+} \chi_{\{u>0\}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right] \\
& =r^{-1}\left[(n+1) \int_{B_{1}} x_{n}^{+} \chi_{\left\{u_{r}>0\right\}} d x-\int_{\partial B_{1}} x_{n}^{+} \chi_{\left\{u_{r}>0\right\}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Let us consider the $3 / 2$-homogeneous replacement of $u_{r}(x)$ defined by

$$
z_{r}(x):=|x|^{3 / 2} u_{r}\left(\frac{x}{|x|}\right)=\frac{|x|^{3 / 2}}{r^{3 / 2}} u\left(r \frac{x}{|x|}\right), \quad x \in B_{1}
$$

It follows from a direct calculation that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{B_{1} \cap\left\{z_{r}>0\right\}} x_{n}^{+} d x & =\int_{0}^{1} \int_{\mathbb{S}^{n-1} \cap\left\{z_{r}>0\right\}} \rho^{n} \cos \theta_{n-1} d \rho d \theta \\
& =\frac{1}{n+1} \int_{\partial B_{1} \cap\left\{u_{r}>0\right\}} x_{n}^{+} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used $z_{r}=u_{r}$ on $\partial B_{1}$. This, together with (7.12), implies that

$$
\Pi^{\prime \prime}(r)=(n+1) r^{-1}\left[\int_{B_{1}} x_{n}^{+} \chi_{\left\{u_{r}>0\right\}} d x-\int_{B_{1}} x_{n}^{+} \chi_{\left\{z_{r}>0\right\}} d x\right]
$$

Note that if $x \in\left\{u_{r}<z_{r}\right\} \cap B_{1}$, then $\Pi^{\prime \prime}(r)<0$ and this implies that $\Pi(r)<$ $r \Pi^{\prime}(0)=0$ for $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$, where we used the fact that $\chi_{\{u>0\}} \rightarrow \chi_{0}=1$ since $0 \in \Sigma_{u}$. However, this contradicts to the fact that $\Pi(r) \geqslant 0$. Thus, we have $u_{r} \geqslant z_{r}$ in $B_{1}$ and that $\Pi^{\prime \prime}(r) \geqslant 0$ for $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ and this gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 \leqslant \Pi(r) & =\Pi(r)-\Pi(0)=\Pi^{\prime}(\tilde{r}) r \leqslant \Pi^{\prime}(r) r \\
& =r^{-n} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

This, together with (7.9) and (7.10), gives that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2}\left(K_{1}(u ; t)+K_{2}(u ; t)\right) d t \\
& \geqslant-\left|\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} K_{1}(u ; t) d t\right|+\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} K_{2}(u ; t) d t \\
& \geqslant-\mathscr{C} \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-1} \int_{B_{t}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x d t \\
& \geqslant-\mathscr{C} r^{-n} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\left|\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2}\left(K_{1}(u ; t)+K_{2}(u ; t)\right) d t\right|}{r^{-n-1} \int_{\bar{B}_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}=0
$$

We now consider $\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2}\left(K_{3}(u ; t)+K_{4}(u ; t)\right) d t$. Under the growth assumption $|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{+}$, we may deduce from $\partial_{1} H<0$ that $H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \geqslant$ $H\left(x_{n} ; x_{n}\right)=\bar{\rho}_{0}$. This implies that

$$
\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} \geqslant 0 \quad \text { in } \bar{B}_{r}
$$

It follows from the definition of $K_{2}(u ; r)$ and $K_{3}(u ; r)$ that $K_{3}(u ; r) \geqslant 0$ for all $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ and $K_{3}(u ; r) \geqslant 0$ in $\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \leqslant 0\right\}$ where $u_{\nu}:=\nabla u \cdot \nu$. Therefore it suffices to consider the case when $\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right)$ in $\partial B_{r} \cap$ $\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}$. Then a direct calculation gives that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r) \\
& \geqslant 3 \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right) u\left(\nabla u \cdot \nu-\frac{3}{2} \frac{u}{r}\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& =\frac{9}{2} \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) \frac{u^{2}}{r} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& -3 \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u \nabla u \cdot \nu d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& \geqslant \frac{9}{2} \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) \frac{u^{2}}{r} \chi_{\{u>0\}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& -3 \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u \nabla u \cdot \nu d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& =\frac{9}{2} \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) \frac{u^{2}}{r}\left(\chi_{\{u>0\}}-1\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +3 \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u\left(\frac{3}{2} \frac{u}{r}-\nabla u \cdot \nu\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& \geqslant \frac{9}{2} \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) \frac{u^{2}}{r}\left(\chi_{\{u>0\}}-1\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +3 \int_{\partial B_{r} \cap\left\{u_{\nu} \geqslant 0\right\}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u \nabla u \cdot \nu\left(\chi_{\{u>0\}}-1\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here in the last inequality, we used the fact that $\frac{u}{r} \geqslant \frac{u}{r} \chi_{\{u>0\}}=\frac{2}{5} u_{\nu} \chi_{\{u>0\}}$ for any $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$ with $r_{0}$ sufficiently small, and this can be deduced from. Thanks to (7.3), one has

$$
K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r) \geqslant-r^{2} \mathscr{C} \int_{\partial B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
$$

This implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2}\left(K_{3}(u ; t)+K_{4}(u ; t)\right) d t \\
& \geqslant-\mathscr{C} \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n} \int_{\partial B_{t}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, a direct computation gives that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n} \int_{\partial B_{t}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} d t \\
& =\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n} \frac{d}{d t} \int_{B_{t}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x d t \\
& =r^{-n} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x \\
& +n \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-1} \int_{B_{t}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x d t
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (7.11) and (7.13) that

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\left|\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2}\left(K_{3}(u ; t)+K_{4}(u ; t)\right) d t\right|}{r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}=0
$$

It now follows from (7.8), (7.14) and (7.15) that there exists $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ sufficiently small so that

$$
\left|r^{-n-1} K_{1}(u ; r)\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C} \varepsilon r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x
$$

for some universal $\mathscr{C}$, and

$$
\left|\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}(u ; t) d t\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C} \varepsilon r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x
$$

for all $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$ and all $\varepsilon>0$ sufficiently small.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& r^{-n-1} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+r^{-n-2} e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \\
& \geqslant r^{-n-1} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x \\
& -r^{-n-1}\left|K_{1}(r)\right|-\left|\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}(t) d t\right| \\
& \geqslant \mathscr{C} r^{-n-2}(1-\varepsilon) \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x \geqslant 0
\end{aligned}
$$

(3). (3). Recalling (4.24), we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial}{\partial r} W(u ; r) \\
& =2 r^{-1}\left(r^{-n-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u \nabla u \cdot \nu}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}-\frac{3}{2} r^{-n-2} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right. \\
& \left.+r^{-n-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u \nabla u \cdot \nu d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right) \\
& =2 r^{-1}\left(r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x-\frac{3}{2} r^{-n-2} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right. \\
& \left.+r^{-n-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u \nabla u \cdot \nu d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we deduce from the definition of $K_{4}(u ; r)$ that $K_{4}(u ; r) \geqslant 0$ for all $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$. Since $\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right)=0$. We obtain that $K_{3}(u ; r) \leqslant 0$ for $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$ with $r_{0}>0$ sufficiently small. Since $\frac{1}{H}-\frac{1}{H_{0}} \leqslant 0$, we deduce from the definition of $K_{3}(u ; r)$ that $u_{\nu}=\frac{5}{2} \frac{u}{r} \geqslant 0$ for any $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$. Thus, (7.16) implies that $\frac{\partial}{\partial r} W(u ; r) \geqslant 0$ for all $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$. The proof is concluded.
7.3. A frequency formula for the horizontal flat points. Recalling the inequality (7.4), which states that for every degenerate stagnation points $x^{\circ}$ and for each subsonic variational solution $u$ of (3.4),

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}-\frac{3}{2} \\
& \geqslant \frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{1}{H_{0}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{1}{H_{0}} u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

In this subsection, we study the quantitative results for the left-hand side of the above inequality. For the sake of notations, we define

$$
D\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right):=\frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
$$

and

$$
V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right):=\frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{1}{H_{0}} x_{n}^{+}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{1}{H_{0}} u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
$$

where $e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ is defined by

$$
e\left(x^{n}, u ; r\right)=r^{n+2} \int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; t\right) d t+r K_{1}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)
$$

Here $K_{i}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ is defined in (4.13), (4.14), (4.15) and (4.16).
Theorem 7.7 (Frequency formula). Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4) and let $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$. Then for a.e. $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ let us consider the functions $D\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right), V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ and $e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ defined in (7.17), (7.18) and (7.5), respectively. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) & :=D\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \\
& =\frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}+\frac{x_{n}^{+}}{H_{0}}\left(\chi_{\{u>0\}}-1\right) d x-e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

satisfies for a.e. $r \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial r} N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) & =\frac{2}{r^{n+3} W\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-D\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +\frac{2}{r} V^{2}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)+\frac{2}{r} V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)\left[N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \\
& +\frac{\frac{2}{3} K_{3}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left[N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \\
& -\frac{K_{4}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial r} N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) & =\frac{2}{r^{n+3} W\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{\left[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) u\right]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +\frac{2}{r} V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)\left[N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \\
& +\frac{\frac{2}{3} K_{3}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left[N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right]-\frac{K_{4}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& +\frac{2}{r} V^{2}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \frac{\mathcal{J}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& +\frac{4 V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{r}\left[N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \frac{\mathcal{J}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& +\frac{3 V(r)}{r} \frac{\mathcal{J}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{J}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right):=\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right) u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
$$

Proof. Assume without loss of generality that $x^{\circ}=0 \in \Sigma^{u}$ and we write $D(r), N(r)$ and $V(r)$ for the sake os notations. Let us define

$$
\widetilde{U}(r):=U(r)-\int_{0}^{r} t^{-n-2} \sum_{i=1}^{4} K_{i}(t) d t
$$

then it follows from the definition of $N(u ; r)$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
N(r) & =\frac{\widetilde{U}(r)-\frac{2}{3 H_{0}}}{W(r)} \\
& =\frac{\widetilde{U}(r)-r^{-n-1} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \int_{B_{r}} x_{n}^{+} d x}{W(r)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We now proceed a direct calculation of $N^{\prime}(r)$, which gives

$$
N^{\prime}(r)=\frac{\widetilde{U}^{\prime}(r)}{W(r)}-\frac{\widetilde{U}(r)-r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} \frac{1}{H_{0}} x_{n}^{+} d x}{W(r)} \frac{W^{\prime}(r)}{W(r)}
$$

It then follows from (4.23) and (4.24) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
N^{\prime}(r) & =\frac{\left(2 r \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{(\nabla u \cdot \nu)^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}-3 \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u \nabla u \cdot \nu}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& -(D(r)-V(r)) \frac{1}{r} \frac{\left(2 r \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u \nabla u \cdot \nu}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}-3 \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} H_{0} u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& +\frac{\frac{2}{3} K_{3}(r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left[(D(r)-V(r))-\frac{3}{2}\right]-\frac{K_{4}(r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
N^{\prime}(r) & =\frac{2}{r}\left(\frac{r^{2} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{(\nabla u \cdot \nu)^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}-\frac{3}{2} D(r)\right) \\
& -\frac{2}{r}(D(r)-V(r))\left[D(r)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \\
& +\frac{\frac{2}{3} K_{3}(r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left(N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right)-\frac{K_{4}(r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from the definition of $D(r)$ that

$$
D(r)=\frac{r \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u \nabla u \cdot \nu}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
$$

This gives that

$$
\frac{r^{2} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{(\nabla u \cdot \nu)^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}-D^{2}(r)=\frac{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-D(r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{1}}
$$

This proves (7.19).
Since $D(u ; r)=N(u ; r)+V(u ; r)$, we obtain

$$
\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-D(u ; r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-N(u ; r) u-V(u ; r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& =\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-N(u ; r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& -2 V(u ; r) r \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u \nabla u \cdot \nu}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +2 N(u ; r) V(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +V^{2}(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

With the aid of (7.21), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-D(u ; r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& =\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-N(u ; r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& -2 D(u ; r) V(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +V^{2}(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +2 N(u ; r) V(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, introducing $N(r)=D(r)-V(r)$ into the last integral yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-D(u ; r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& =\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-N(u ; r) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}-V^{2}(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +2 D(u ; r) V(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right) u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& -V^{2}(u ; r) \int_{\partial B_{r}}\left(\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}-\frac{1}{H_{0}}\right) u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Introducing the above identity give (7.20).
Let us now collect some properties of $D\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right), V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ and the frequency function $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$.

Proposition 7.8. Let $u$ be a variational solution of (3.4), let $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{n}$ and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Then there exists $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ sufficiently small so that the following holds:
(1) $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \geqslant \frac{3}{2}$ for all $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$.
(2) $V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \geqslant 0$ in $\left(0, r_{0}\right)$.
(3) $r \mapsto \frac{1}{r} V^{2}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \in L^{1}\left(0, r_{0}\right)$.
(4) The function $r \mapsto N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ has a right limit $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$. Moreover, $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right) \geqslant \frac{3}{2}$.
(5) The function

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial}{\partial r} N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \\
& -\frac{2 H_{0}}{r^{n+3} W\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) u]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

is bounded below by a function in $L^{1}\left(0, r_{0}\right)$.
Proof. The statements (1) and (2) follow from the definition in (7.17), (7.18) and Lemma 7.6 (2) directly.
(3). Assume that $x^{\circ}=0$ and let us consider the following two possibilities.

Case I. If $N(u ; r) \geqslant \frac{5}{2}$. Then $N(u ; r)-\frac{5}{2} \geqslant 1$. It follows from $|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+}$ that $K_{4}(u ; r) \geqslant 0$, thus,

$$
\frac{K_{4}(u ; r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}^{2}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \leqslant \frac{K_{4}(u ; r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}^{2}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left[N(u ; r)-\frac{5}{2}\right]
$$

The frequency formula in (7.19) gives

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(N(r)-\frac{3}{2}\right) \geqslant-\beta\left(N(r)-\frac{3}{2}\right)
$$

for some $\beta>0$. It follows that

$$
r \mapsto e^{\beta r}\left(N(r)-\frac{3}{2}\right) \quad \text { is nondecreasing on }\left(0, r_{0}\right)
$$

Thus, if we set $g(r):=e^{\beta r}\left(N(r)-\frac{3}{2}\right)$, we have that $g(r) \leqslant g\left(r_{0}\right):=c_{0}$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\left|K_{3}(u ; r)\right|}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left(N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right) \\
& \geqslant-\frac{\left|K_{3}(u ; r)\right|}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left(N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right) \\
& =-\frac{\left|K_{3}(u ; r)\right|}{\left(\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right) e^{\beta r}} e^{\beta r}\left(N(r)-\frac{3}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\geqslant-\frac{\mathscr{C}\left|K_{4}(u ; r)\right|}{\left(\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right) e^{\beta r}} c_{0} \geqslant-\mathscr{C}
$$

where we used $\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right)=0$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|K_{4}(u ; r)\right| & =\left|\frac{9}{2 r} \int_{\partial B_{r}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right| \\
& \leqslant \mathscr{C} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, in this case we obtain that

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial r} N(u ; r) \geqslant \frac{1}{r} V^{2}(r)-\mathscr{C}
$$

Since by the first part (1), $N(u ; r)$ is bounded below as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, the integrability of $r \mapsto \frac{1}{r} V^{2}(u ; r)$ follows immediately.

Case II. If $N(u ; r) \in\left[\frac{3}{2}, \frac{5}{2}\right)$. Let us consider the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varphi(r) & :=\frac{1}{r} V(u ; r)\left(N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right) \\
& +\frac{\frac{3}{4}\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\left(N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (7.19) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial r} N(u ; r) & =\frac{2}{r^{n+3} W\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{\left[r(\nabla u \cdot \nu)-D\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) u\right]^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& +\frac{2}{r} V^{2}(u ; r)+\frac{1}{r} V(u ; r)\left[N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right] \\
& +\varphi(r)-N(u ; r) \frac{K_{4}(r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (7.22) and $N(u ; r)<\frac{5}{2}$ that

$$
\left|\frac{N(u ; r) K_{4}(u ; r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\right| \leqslant \mathscr{C}_{1}
$$

Moreover, it follows from the definition of $\varphi(r)$ that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\varphi(r) & =\left(N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{r} V(u ; r)+\frac{\frac{2}{3}\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\right) \\
& =\left(N(u ; r)-\frac{3}{2}\right) \\
& \times\left(\frac{\int_{B_{r}} \frac{x_{n}^{2}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+r^{-1} e(u ; r)+\frac{2}{3}\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows from (7.8), (7.14) and a similar argument as in Lemma 7.6 (3) that

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\left|r^{-1} e(u ; r)+\frac{2}{3}\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right)\right|}{\int_{B_{r}} \frac{x_{n}^{2}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}=0
$$

Therefore we can deduce that there exists $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ small so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{B_{r}} \frac{x_{n}^{+}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+r^{-1} e(u ; r)+\frac{2}{3}\left(K_{3}(u ; r)+K_{4}(u ; r)\right) \\
& \geqslant(1-\varepsilon) \int_{B_{r}} \frac{x_{n}^{+}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x \geqslant 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we can infer from (7.23) that

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial r} N(u ; r) \geqslant \frac{1}{r} V^{2}(u ; r)-\mathscr{C}
$$

and the integrability of $r \mapsto \frac{1}{r} V^{2}(u ; r)$ follows immediately.
(4). By the first statement, $r \mapsto N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ is bounded below as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$. We also deduce from (3) that $N(r)$ has a limit as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, and that $N\left(0^{+}\right) \geqslant \frac{3}{2}$, thus proving this statement.
(5). Along with a similar argument as (3) and we omit it here.

Corollary 7.9. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4) and suppose that $u$ satisfies

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Then the function

$$
x \mapsto N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)
$$

is upper semi-continuous on the closed set $\Sigma^{u}$.
Proof. Let us define

$$
\widetilde{N}(r)=\widetilde{N}(x, u ; r):=N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)-\int_{0}^{r}\left(\frac{1}{t} V^{2}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; t\right)-\mathscr{C}\right) d t
$$

Then it follows that $\frac{\partial}{\partial r} \widetilde{N}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right) \geqslant 0$. Moreover, since $r \mapsto \frac{1}{r} V^{2}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ is integrable on $\left(0, r_{0}\right)$, we can deduce that $\widetilde{N}\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)=N\left(x, u ; 0^{+}\right)$for all $x$. Here the existence of the limit follows from Proposition 7.8 (3). Therefore for each $\delta>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
N\left(x, u ; 0^{+}\right) & =\widetilde{N}\left(x, u ; 0^{+}\right) \leqslant \widetilde{N}(x, u ; r) \\
& \leqslant N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)+C r \leqslant N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)+\frac{\delta}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

if we choose for fixed $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$ first $r>0$ and then $\left|x-x^{\circ}\right|$ small enough.

The next result improves Lemma 7.6 at those points of $\Sigma^{u}$ at which the frequency function is greater than $\frac{3}{2}$.

Lemma 7.10. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4), let $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$ and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Suppose that $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)>\frac{3}{2}$ and let us set $N_{0}:=N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$. Then there exists $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ sufficiently small so that
(1) There exists $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ sufficiently small so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}-N_{0} \\
& \geqslant \frac{r \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{x_{n}^{+}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \geqslant 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where $e\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)$ is defined in (7.5).
(2) The function

$$
r \mapsto \frac{r^{1-n-2 N_{0}}}{H_{0}} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} u^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
$$

is non-decreasing on $\left(0, r_{0}\right)$.
(3) For each $\alpha \in\left[0, N_{0}\right)$,

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{\alpha}} \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { strongly in } L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \quad \text { as } r \rightarrow 0^{+}
$$

Proof. Assume $x^{\circ}=0$. (1). The first statement follows from the fact that $N(u ; r) \geqslant N_{0}$ and $V(u ; r) \geqslant 0$ for all $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$ (cf. Proposition 7.8 (1) and (2)).
(2). It follows from the previous statement $N(u ; r) \geqslant N_{0}$ and the definition of $N(u ; r)$ that

$$
\frac{r \int_{B_{r}} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}-N_{0} \geqslant \frac{r \int_{B_{r}} \frac{x_{n}^{+}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x+e(r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
$$

Thanks to the third statement of Proposition 7.8 we have

$$
\frac{r \int_{B_{r}} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}-N_{0} \geqslant 0
$$

for all $r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)$ and all $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$. We compute directly to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(r^{1-n-2 N_{0}} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right) \\
& =2 r^{2-2 N_{0}}\left(r^{-n-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u \nabla u \cdot \nu}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}-N_{0} r^{-n-2} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right. \\
& \left.+r^{-n-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u \nabla u \cdot \nu d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right) \\
& =2 r^{2-2 N_{0}}\left(r^{-n-1} \int_{B_{r}} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x-N_{0} r^{-n-2} \int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right. \\
& \left.+r^{-n-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}}\left(\frac{1}{H_{0}}-\frac{1}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right) u \nabla u \cdot \nu d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used (7.24) in the last inequality. The rest of the proof follows as in Lemma 7.6 (3).
(3). It is a consequence of the part (2) that $r \mapsto r^{-n-2 N_{0}} H_{0} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} u^{2} d x$ is non-decreasing on $\left(0, r_{0}\right)$ and therefore, for each $\alpha \in\left[0, N_{0}\right)$,

$$
r^{-n-2 \alpha} \int_{B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} u^{2} d x \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } r \rightarrow 0^{+}
$$

This implies (3) of the lemma.
7.4. The frequency sequence. The frequency formula allows us passing to blow-up limits. We consider the following blow-up sequence

$$
v_{m}(x):=\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r_{m} x\right)}{\sqrt{r_{m}^{1-n} \int_{\partial B_{r_{m}}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}}
$$

Our first observation related to $v_{m}$ is concluded in the following lemma.
Lemma 7.11. Let $u$ be a variational solution of (3.4), let $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$, and assume that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Then for any sequence $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$, the sequence defined in (7.25) satisfies, for every $0<\sigma_{1}<\sigma_{2}<1$,

$$
\int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{\left|\nabla v_{m} \cdot x-N\left(0^{+}\right) v_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } m \rightarrow+\infty
$$

where $H_{m}\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right):=H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)$.
Proof. Assume without loss of generality that $0 \in \Sigma^{u}$. It follows by rescaling that for every $0<\sigma_{1}<\sigma_{2}<\infty$ and for all $r_{m}<\delta_{0}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\sigma_{1}}^{\sigma_{2}} \frac{2}{r} \frac{H_{0}}{\left(\left|\nabla u\left(r_{m} x\right)\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)} \int_{\partial B_{r}} v_{m}^{2} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} d r \\
& \leqslant N\left(u ; r_{m} \sigma_{2}\right)-N\left(u ; r_{m} \sigma_{1}\right) \\
& +\int_{r_{m} \sigma_{1}}^{r_{m} \sigma_{2}}\left(\mathscr{C}_{1}+\mathscr{C}_{2} \frac{1}{r} V^{2}(u ; r)\right) d r \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

as $m \rightarrow+\infty$, as a consequence of Proposition 7.8 (3) and (4). Observe now that for all $r \in\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right) \subset(0,1)$ and all $m$ as above, we can deduce from Lemma 7.6 (3) that

$$
\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{v_{m}^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}=\frac{\int_{\partial B_{r r_{m}}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}{\int_{\partial B_{r_{m}}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}=\frac{\left(r r_{m}\right)^{n+2} W\left(u ; r r_{m}\right)}{r_{m}^{n+2} W\left(u ; r_{m}\right)} \leqslant r^{n+2}
$$

as $m \rightarrow+\infty$. Therefore, we deduce from (7.27) and (7.28) that

$$
\int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}|x|^{-n-3} \frac{\left|\nabla v_{m} \cdot x-N\left(r r_{m}\right) v_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x \rightarrow 0
$$

as $m \rightarrow+\infty$. Since $|x| \in\left(\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}\right)$, we obtain (7.26).
As a direct application of Lemma 7.11, we have
Proposition 7.12. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4), let $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$, and assume that $u$ satisfies the growth condition

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{n}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Then the following holds:
(1) There exist

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} V\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)=0
$$

and

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} D\left(x^{\circ}, u ; r\right)=N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)
$$

(2) Let $v_{m}$ be defined in (7.25) for any $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$as $m \rightarrow+\infty$, then the sequence is bounded in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$.

(3) For any sequence $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$as $m \rightarrow+\infty$ such that the sequence $v_{m}$ converges in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$ to a blow-up $v_{0}$, then $v_{0}$ is a homogeneous function of degree $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$in $B_{1}$, and satisfies
$v_{0} \geqslant 0 \quad$ in $\quad B_{1}, \quad v_{0} \equiv 0 \quad$ in $\quad B_{1} \cap\left\{x_{n} \leqslant 0\right\}, \quad \int_{\partial B_{1}} \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}=1$.
Proof. (1). Let $x^{\circ}=0$ and let us define

$$
\widetilde{V}(u ; r)=\frac{r \int_{B_{r}} \frac{x_{n}^{4}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
$$

and

$$
\mathcal{V}(u ; r):=\frac{e(u ; r)}{\int_{\partial B_{r}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
$$

where $e(u ; r)$ is given in (7.5). Then it follows the definition of $V(u ; r)(7.18)$ that $V(u ; r)=\widetilde{V}(u ; r)+\mathcal{V}(u ; r)$. Moreover, we infer from the proof of Lemma 7.6 (2) that $\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\mathcal{V}(u ; r)}{\widetilde{V}(u ; r)}=0$ (cf. (7.8), (7.14) and (7.15)). Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{r} V^{2}(u ; r) & =\frac{1}{r} \widetilde{V}^{2}(u ; r)+\frac{1}{r} \mathcal{V}^{2}(u ; r)+\frac{2}{r} \widetilde{V}(r) \mathcal{V}(u ; r) \\
& \geqslant \frac{1}{r} \widetilde{V}^{2}(u ; r)+\frac{2}{r} \widetilde{V}(u ; r) \mathcal{V}(u ; r)
\end{aligned}
$$

and it follows from $\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\widetilde{V}(u ; r) \mathcal{V}(u ; r)}{\widetilde{V}^{2}(u ; r)}=0$ that there exists $r_{0} \in\left(0, \delta_{0}\right)$ sufficiently small so that

$$
\frac{1}{r} V^{2}(u ; r) \geqslant \frac{1}{r} \widetilde{V}^{2}(u ; r)+\frac{2}{r} \widetilde{V}(u ; r) \mathcal{V}(r) \geqslant \frac{c}{r} \widetilde{V}^{2}(u ; r)
$$
