Then the integrability of $r \mapsto \frac{1}{r} V^{2}(u ; r) \in L^{1}\left(0, r_{0}\right)$ implies the integrability of $r \mapsto \frac{1}{r} \widetilde{V}^{2}(u ; r) \in L^{1}\left(0, r_{0}\right)$.

Suppose now a contradiction that (1) is not true. Let $s_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$be a sequence such that $\widetilde{V}\left(s_{m}\right)$ is bounded away from 0 . Due to the integrability of $r \mapsto \frac{2}{r} \widetilde{V}^{2}(r)$ we have that

$$
\min _{r \in\left[s_{m}, s_{2 m}\right]} \widetilde{V}(r) \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } m \rightarrow+\infty
$$

Let $t_{m} \in\left[s_{m}, s_{2 m}\right]$ be such that $\widetilde{V}\left(t_{m}\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $m \rightarrow+\infty$. For the choice $r_{m}:=t_{m}$ for each $m$, the sequence $v_{m}$ defined in (7.25) satisfies (7.26). The fact that $\widetilde{V}\left(r_{m}\right) \rightarrow 0$ implies $\mathcal{V}\left(r_{m}\right) \rightarrow 0$ and thus $V\left(r_{m}\right) \rightarrow 0$, this further gives that $D\left(r_{m}\right)$ is bounded since $N\left(0^{+}\right)$has a right limit. Observe now that

$$
\int_{B_{r_{m}}} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2}}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x=r_{m}^{n} \int_{B_{1}} \frac{\left|\nabla u\left(r_{m} x\right)\right|^{2}}{H\left(\left|\nabla u\left(r_{m} x\right)\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)} d x
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =r_{m}^{-1} \int_{\partial B_{r_{m}}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \int_{B_{1}} \frac{\left|\nabla v_{m}\right|^{2}}{H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)} d x \\
& =r_{m}^{-1} \int_{\partial B_{r_{m}}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \int_{B_{1}} \frac{\left|\nabla v_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

it follows from (7.17) and (7.25) that

$$
D\left(u ; r_{m}\right)=\frac{r_{m} \int_{B_{r_{m}}} \frac{|\nabla u|^{2} d x}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}}{\int_{\partial B_{r_{m}}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}=\int_{B_{1}} \frac{\left|\nabla v_{m}\right|^{2}}{H_{m}\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} d x
$$

This combined with the boundedness of $D\left(u ; r_{m}\right)$ and $H_{m} \geqslant H_{0}$ for all $m$ that $v_{m}$ is bounded in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$. Let $v_{0}$ be any weak limit of $v_{m}$ along a subsequence. Note that by the compact embedding $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right) \hookrightarrow L^{2}\left(\partial B_{1}\right)$, $\left\|v_{0}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\partial B_{1}\right)}=1$, since this is true for $v_{m}$ for all $m$. It then follows from (7.26) that $v_{0}$ is a homogeneous function of degree $N\left(u ; 0^{+}\right)$. Note that, by using Lemma 7.6 (3),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{V}\left(s_{m}\right) & =\frac{s_{m}^{-n-1} \int_{B_{s_{m}}} \frac{x_{n}^{+}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}{s_{m}^{-n-2} \int_{\partial B_{s_{m}}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& \leqslant \frac{s_{m}^{-n-1} \int_{B_{s_{m}}} \frac{x_{n}^{+}}{H_{0}}\left(1-\chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) d x}{\left(r_{m} / 2\right)^{-n-2} \int_{\partial B_{r_{m} / 2}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \\
& \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \frac{\int_{\partial B_{r_{m}}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}{\int_{\partial B_{r_{m} / 2}} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}} \widetilde{V}\left(u ; r_{m}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \frac{\widetilde{V}\left(u ; r_{m}\right)}{\int_{\partial B_{1 / 2}} \frac{v_{m}^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since, at least along a subsequence,

$$
\int_{\partial B_{1 / 2}} \frac{v_{m}^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \rightarrow \int_{\partial B_{1 / 2}} \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}>0
$$

we deduce that (7.30) leads to a contradiction to our choice of $s_{m}$. It follows indeed that $\widetilde{V}(u ; r) \rightarrow 0$ as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, it then follows from $\mathcal{V}(u ; r)=o(\widetilde{V}(u ; r))$ that $\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \mathcal{V}(r)=0$. This gives $\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} V(r)=0$ and $D(r) \rightarrow N\left(0^{+}\right)$.
(2). Let $r_{m}$ be any sequence be such that $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$. In view of (7.29), we know that the boundedness of $v_{m}$ is equivalent to the boundedness of $D\left(u ; r_{m}\right)$.
(3). Let $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$be such that $v_{m}$ converges weakly to $v_{0}$ along a subsequence. Let us now recall (7.26). It follows from the fact that

$$
H\left(\left|\nabla u\left(r_{m} x\right)\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right) \leqslant \mathscr{C}
$$

for all $m$ and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{\left[\nabla v_{m} \cdot x-N\left(u ; r r_{m}\right) v_{m}\right]^{2}}{H\left(\left|\nabla u\left(r_{m} x\right)\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)} d x \\
& \geqslant e \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}\left[\nabla v_{m} \cdot x-N\left(u ; r r_{m}\right) v_{m}\right]^{2} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies that

$$
\int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}\left[x \cdot \nabla v_{m}-N\left(u ; r r_{m}\right) v_{m}\right]^{2} d x \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } m \rightarrow+\infty
$$

Since the functional $w \mapsto \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}\left|\nabla w \cdot x-N\left(0^{+}\right) w\right|^{2} d x$ is convex, and thus lower semi-continuity under weak convergence in $W^{1,2}$ gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}\left[\nabla v_{0} \cdot x-N\left(u ; 0^{+}\right) v_{0}\right]^{2} d x \\
& \leqslant \lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty} \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}\left[\nabla v_{m} \cdot x-N\left(u ; r r_{m}\right) v_{m}\right]^{2} d x=0
\end{aligned}
$$

The homogeneity of $v_{0}$ follows. This concludes the proof since $\int_{\partial B_{1}} \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{H_{0}}=1$ is a direct consequence of $\int_{\partial B_{1}} \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{H_{0}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}=1$.
7.5. Compensated compactness. In this subsection we will apply a compensated compactness result which allows us to preserve subsonic variational solutions in the blow-up limit at degenerate stagnation points and exclude the concentration. To this end, we combine the compensated compactness result in $[13,15]$ with information we gained by our frequency formula. More precisely, we use the compensated compactness to prove the weak convergence of the nonlinear, quadratic terms $\rho_{m} u_{1, m} \cdot \nabla u_{1, m}$ appeared in Euler system. Additionally, we obtain strong convergence of blow-up sequence which is necessary to prove our main result.

Proposition 7.13. Let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4) for $n=2$, let $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$ and suppose that $u$ satisfies the growth condition

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Let $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$be such that the sequence $v_{m}$ defined in (7.25) converges weakly to $v_{0}$ in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$. Then $v_{m}$ converges to $v_{0}$ strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(B_{1} \backslash\{0\}\right)$, and $v_{0}$ satisfies $v_{0} \frac{\Delta v_{0}}{H_{0}}=0$ in the sense of Radon measures on $B_{1}$.

Proof. Notice first that

$$
v_{m}(x)=\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r_{m} x\right)}{\sqrt{r_{m}^{-1} \int_{\partial B_{r_{m}}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d S}}=\frac{r_{m}^{3 / 2} u_{m}(x)}{\sqrt{\int_{\partial B_{1}} \frac{u^{2}\left(x^{\circ}+r_{m} x\right)}{H_{0}} d S}}=\frac{u_{m}(x)}{\sqrt{\int_{\partial B_{1}} \frac{u_{m}^{2}}{H_{0}} d S}}
$$

Given that $u_{m}$ satisfies $\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla u_{m}}{H_{m}}\right)=0$ in $\left\{u_{m}>0\right\}$ where

$$
H_{m}:=H\left(r_{m}\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; r_{m} x_{n}\right)
$$

we can deduce that

$$
\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla v_{m}}{H_{m}}\right)=0 \quad \text { in }\left\{v_{m}>0\right\}
$$

On the other hand, thanks to the fact that $\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla u}{H\left(\left|\nabla u\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right)$ is a non-negative Radon measure on $B_{1}$, we have that for arbitrary $0<\varrho<\sigma<1$

$$
\left(\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla v_{m}}{H_{m}}\right)\right)\left(B_{(\sigma+1) / 2}\right) \leqslant C_{1} \quad \text { for all } m
$$

and that

$$
\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla v_{m}}{H_{m}}\right) \geqslant 0 \quad \text { on } B_{1}
$$

That is, take any non-negative $\eta \in C_{0}^{\infty}\left(B_{1}\right)$, we have

$$
\int_{B_{1}} \frac{\nabla v_{m} \nabla \eta}{H_{m}} d x \leqslant 0, \quad \text { for all } m
$$

It is easy to verify that $H_{m} \rightarrow H_{0}$ strongly in $L^{2}\left(B_{1}\right)$. Thus, since $\nabla v_{m} \rightarrow$ $\nabla v_{0}$ weakly in $L^{2}\left(B_{1}\right)$, we have

$$
\int_{B_{1}} \frac{\nabla v_{0} \nabla \eta}{H_{0}} d x=\lim _{m \rightarrow+\infty} \int_{B_{1}} \frac{\nabla v_{m} \nabla \eta}{H_{m}} d x \leqslant 0
$$

This implies that $\frac{\Delta v_{0}}{H_{0}}$ is a non-negative Radon measure supported on $B_{1}$, since $v_{0}$ is continuous in $B_{1}$, we deduce that $v_{0} \frac{\Delta v_{0}}{H_{0}}$ is well defined as a non-negative Radon measure on $B_{1}$. Note that it is at present not clear that $v_{m} \rightarrow v_{0}$ strongly in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}\right)$. In order to improve that weak convergence to the strong convergence, we actually need to pass any PDE for $v_{m}$ so that we can "shield" the PDE from the failure of strong convergence. Here we will employ the method of "compensated compactness framework". We now state them for the sake of completeness. Let now $\left(u_{1, m}, u_{2, m}, \rho_{m}\right)$ be a sequence of approximate solutions to the Euler equations

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\partial_{x_{1}}\left(\rho_{m} u_{1, m}\right)+\partial_{x_{2}}\left(\rho_{m} u_{2, m}\right)=0 \\
\partial_{x_{1}}\left(\rho_{m} u_{1, m}^{2}\right)+\partial_{x_{2}}\left(\rho_{m} u_{1, m} u_{2, m}\right)+\partial_{x_{1}} p_{m}=0 \\
\partial_{x_{1}}\left(\rho_{m} u_{1, m} u_{2, m}\right)+\partial_{x_{2}}\left(\rho_{m} u_{2, m}^{2}\right)+\partial_{x_{2}} p_{m}+\rho_{m} g=0 \\
\partial_{x_{2}} u_{1, m}-\partial_{x_{1}} u_{2, m}=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

It was proved in [13, Theorem 2.1] (also see the [14, Section 9] and [40] for the case when there is an external force) that if $\left(\rho_{m}, u_{1, m}, u_{2, m}\right)$ satisfies
(1) $u_{1, m}^{2}+u_{2, m}^{2} \leqslant \sqrt{p^{\prime}\left(\rho_{m}\right)}$ a.e. in $\Omega$,

(2) $\frac{u_{1, m}^{2}+u_{2, m}^{2}}{2}+h\left(\rho_{m}\right)-\frac{p^{\prime}\left(\bar{\rho}_{0}\right)}{2}+g x_{2}$ are uniformly bounded.
(3) $\operatorname{curl}\left(u_{1, m}, u_{2, m}\right)=\left(u_{1, m}\right)_{x_{2}}-\left(u_{2, m}\right)_{x_{1}}$ is a bounded measure.

Then there exists a subsequence (still labeled) $\left(\rho_{m}, u_{1, m}, u_{2, m}\right)$ that converges a.e. as $m \rightarrow+\infty$ a weak solution $\left(\bar{\rho}, \bar{u}_{1}, \bar{u}_{2}\right)$ to the Euler equations of (7.34), which satisfies $\bar{u}_{1}^{2}+\bar{u}_{2}^{2} \leqslant \sqrt{p^{\prime}(\bar{\rho})}$. Notice that a weak solution $\left(\rho, u_{1}, u_{2}\right)$ of (7.34) is defined by (cf. [14, Definition 2.1])

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\int_{\Omega}\left(\rho u_{1} \eta_{x_{1}}+\rho u_{2} \eta_{x_{2}}\right) d x=0 \\
\int_{\Omega}\left(\left(\rho u_{1}^{2}+p\right) \eta_{x_{1}}+\rho u_{1} u_{2} \eta_{x_{2}}\right) d x=0 \\
\int_{\Omega}\left(\left(\rho u_{1} u_{2}\right) \eta_{x_{1}}+\left(\rho u_{2}^{2}+p\right) \eta_{x_{2}}+\rho g \eta\right) d x=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

for any $\eta \in C_{0}^{1}(\Omega)$. We can deduce from the compensated compactness framework the weak convergence of the nonlinear, quadratic terms $\rho_{m} u_{1, m}$. $\nabla u_{1, m}$. More precisely,

$$
\rho_{m} u_{1, m} u_{2, m} \rightarrow \bar{\rho} \bar{u}_{1} \bar{u}_{2} \quad \text { in the sense of distributions. }
$$

We now apply such convergence to our models, we first modify each $v_{m}$ and $H_{m}$ to

$$
\tilde{v}_{m}:=v_{m} * \phi_{m} \in C^{\infty}\left(B_{1}\right), \quad \tilde{H}_{m}:=H_{m} * \phi_{m} \in C^{\infty}\left(B_{1}\right)
$$

where $\phi_{m}$ is a standard mollifier such that $\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla \tilde{v}_{m}}{H_{m}}\right) \geqslant 0$ and

$$
\left(\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla \tilde{v}_{m}}{\tilde{H}_{m}}\right)\right)\left(B_{\sigma}\right) \leqslant \mathscr{C}_{2} \quad \text { for all } m
$$

and

$$
\left\|v_{m}-\tilde{v}_{m}\right\|_{W^{1,2}\left(B_{\sigma}\right)} \rightarrow 0 \quad\left\|\tilde{H}_{m}-H_{m}\right\|_{W^{1,2}\left(B_{\sigma}\right)} \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } m \rightarrow+\infty
$$

Let us define $\rho_{m}:=H_{m}$ and consider the associated velocity fields defined by $\left(u_{1, m}, u_{2, m}\right):=\left(\frac{\partial_{1} \tilde{v}_{m}}{\rho_{m}},-\frac{\partial_{1} \tilde{v}_{m}}{\rho_{m}}\right)$ and $\left(\bar{u}_{1}, \bar{u}_{2}\right):=\left(\frac{\partial_{2} v_{0}}{\bar{\rho}_{0}},-\frac{\partial_{1} v_{0}}{\bar{\rho}_{0}}\right)$. Since the flow is uniformly subsonic near each stagnation points (see Property 1.1), and that the Bernoulli function are uniformly bounded in $B_{1}$ for all $m$. Moreover, $\operatorname{div}\left(\rho_{m} u_{m}\right)=0$ and it follows from (7.36) that $\operatorname{curl} \tilde{\mathbf{u}}_{m}=\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla \tilde{v}_{m}}{\rho_{m}}\right)$ are bounded measures in $B_{1}$. Thus we infer from (7.35) and (7.37) that

$$
\frac{1}{H_{m}} \partial_{1} v_{m} \partial_{2} v_{m} \rightarrow \frac{1}{H_{0}} \partial_{1} v_{0} \partial_{2} v_{0} \quad \text { in the sense of distributions, }
$$

on $B_{\sigma}$ as $m \rightarrow+\infty$. Let us remark that in contrast to the two-dimensional incompressible problem [60], this alone would not allow us to pass to the limit in the domain variation formula for $v_{m}$.

Observe now that (7.26), (7.31) and (7.32) show that

$$
\nabla v_{m} \cdot x-N\left(0^{+}\right) v_{m} \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { strongly in } L^{2}\left(B_{\sigma} \backslash B_{\varrho}\right)
$$

It then follows from the $L^{2}$ strong convergence of $H_{m} \rightarrow H_{0}$ in $B_{\sigma}$ that

$$
\frac{1}{H_{m}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{m} x_{1}+\partial_{2} v_{m} x_{2}\right) \rightarrow \frac{1}{H_{0}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{0} x_{1}+\partial_{2} v_{0} x_{2}\right)
$$

in the sense of distributions, where we have used the fact that $v_{0}$ is a homogeneous function of degree $N\left(0^{+}\right)$. But then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{1}{H_{m}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{m} \partial_{1} v_{m} x_{1}+\partial_{1} v_{m} \partial_{2} v_{m} x_{2}\right) \eta d x \\
& \rightarrow \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{1}{H_{0}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{0} \partial_{1} v_{0} x_{1}+\partial_{1} v_{0} \partial_{2} v_{0} x_{2}\right) \eta d x
\end{aligned}
$$

for each $\eta \in C_{0}^{0}\left(B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash \bar{B}_{\sigma_{1}}\right)$. Using (7.38), we obtain that

$$
\int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{1}{H_{m}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{m}\right)^{2} x_{1} \eta d x \rightarrow \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{1}{H_{0}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{0}\right)^{2} x_{1} \eta d x
$$

for each non-negative $\eta \in C_{0}^{0}\left(\left(B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash \bar{B}_{\sigma_{1}}\right) \cap\left\{x_{1}>0\right\}\right)$ and each non-positive $\eta \in C_{0}^{0}\left(\left(B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash \bar{B}_{\sigma_{1}}\right) \cap\left\{x_{1}<0\right\}\right)$ as $m \rightarrow+\infty$. A similar argument as in the proof of Lemma 5.1 Step 2 shows that $\left|H_{m}-H_{0}\right| \leqslant C r_{m}$ for some $C$ independent of $m$. It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{1}{H_{m}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{m}^{2}\right) x_{1} \eta-H_{0}\left(\partial_{1} v_{0}\right)^{2} x_{1} \eta d x \\
& =\int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{1}{\left(H_{m}-H_{0}\right)}\left(\partial_{1} v_{m}\right)^{2} x_{1} \eta d x \\
& +\int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}} \frac{1}{H_{0}}\left[\left(\partial_{1} v_{m}\right)^{2}-\left(\partial_{1} v_{0}\right)^{2}\right] x_{1} \eta d x
\end{aligned}
$$

Passing to the limit as $m \rightarrow+\infty$ and we obtain

$$
\int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{m}\right)^{2} x_{1} \eta d x \rightarrow \int_{B_{\sigma_{2}} \backslash B_{\sigma_{1}}}\left(\partial_{1} v_{0}\right)^{2} x_{1} \eta d x
$$

Repeated the previous arguments gives the strong convergence of $\nabla v_{m} \rightarrow$ $\nabla v_{0}$ in $L_{\text {loc }}^{2}\left(B_{1} \backslash\{0\}\right)$. As a consequence of the strong convergence of $v_{m}$ to $v_{0}$, we have

$$
\int_{B_{1}} \nabla\left(\eta v_{0}\right) \cdot \frac{\nabla v_{0}}{H_{0}} d x=0 \quad \text { for all } \eta \in C_{0}^{1}\left(B_{1} \backslash\{0\}\right)
$$

Combined with the fact that $v_{0}=0$ in $B_{1} \cap\left\{x_{2} \leqslant 0\right\}$, this yields that $v_{0} \frac{\Delta v_{0}}{H_{0}}$ in the sense of Radon measures on $B_{1}$.

With the help of the frequency formula and the compensated compactness argument, we obtain the strong convergence of the frequency functions $v_{m}$ defined in (7.25). In what follows, we will study the limit function $v_{0}$ of $v_{m}$ as $m \rightarrow+\infty$ and will prove qualitative properties for degenerate stagnation points with horizontal flat density.

# 7.6. Horizontal flat points in two dimensions. 

Theorem 7.14. Let $n=2$, let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4), and suppose that $u$ satisfies

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { locally in } \Omega
$$

Then at each degenerate point $x^{\circ}$ of the set $\Sigma^{u}$ there exists an integer $N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \geqslant 2$ such that
$\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{\sqrt{r^{-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{\partial^{2}}{H_{0}} d S}} \rightarrow u_{0}(R, \theta) \equiv \frac{R^{N\left(x^{\circ}\right)}\left|\sin \left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \min \{\max \{\theta, 0\}, \pi\}\right)\right|}{\sqrt{\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \sin ^{2}\left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \theta\right) d \theta}}$,
as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(B_{1} \backslash\{0\}\right)$ and weakly in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$ where $x=$ $(R \cos \theta, R \sin \theta)$.

Proof. Let $r_{m} \rightarrow 0^{+}$be an arbitrary sequence such that the sequence $v_{m}$ given by (7.25) converges weakly in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$ to a blow-up $v_{0}$. By Proposition 7.12 (3) and Proposition 7.13, $v_{0} \not \equiv 0, v_{0}$ is a homogeneous function of degree $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right) \geqslant \frac{3}{2}, v_{0}$ is continuous, $v_{0} \equiv 0$ in $\left\{x_{2} \leqslant 0\right\}, v_{0} \Delta v_{0}=0$ in $B_{1}$ as a Radon measure, and the convergence of $v_{m}$ to $v_{0}$ is strong in $W_{\text {loc }}^{1,2}\left(B_{1} \backslash\{0\}\right)$. The strong convergence of $v_{m}$ and the fact that $V\left(u ; r_{m}\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $m \rightarrow+\infty$ imply that

$$
0=\int_{B_{1}}\left(\left|\nabla v_{0}\right|^{2} \operatorname{div} \phi-2 \nabla v_{0} D \phi \nabla v_{0}\right) d x
$$

for all $\phi \in C_{0}^{1}\left(B_{1} \cap\left\{x_{2}>0\right\} ; \mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$. It follows that in terms of polar coordinates that at each $(1, \theta) \in \partial B_{1} \cap \partial\left\{v_{0}>0\right\}$,

$$
\lim _{\tau \rightarrow \theta^{+}} \partial_{\theta} v_{0}(1, \tau)=-\lim _{\tau \rightarrow \theta^{-}} \partial_{\theta} v_{0}(1, \theta)
$$

Computing the solution of the ordinary differential equation on $\partial B_{1}$, using the homogeneity degree of $N\left(x^{\circ}, u ; 0^{+}\right)$of $v_{0}$ and the fact that $\int_{\partial B_{1}} \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{H_{0}} d S=$ 1 , yields that $N\left(x^{\circ}\right)$ must be an integer $N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \geqslant 2$ and that

$$
v_{0}(R, \theta)=\frac{R^{N\left(x^{\circ}\right)}\left|\sin \left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \min \{\max \{\theta, 0\}, \pi\}\right)\right|}{\sqrt{\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \sin ^{2}\left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \theta\right) d \theta}}
$$

The desired conclusion follows from Proposition 7.12 (2).
Theorem 7.15. Let $n=2$ and let $u$ be a subsonic variational solution of (3.4). Then the set $\Sigma^{u}$ is locally a finite set in $\Omega$.

Proof. Suppose towards a contradiction that there is a sequence of points $x^{m} \in \Sigma^{u}$ converging to $x^{\circ}$ with $x^{m} \neq x^{\circ}$ for all $m$. The upper semi-continuity then implies that $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$. Choosing $r_{m}:=2\left|x^{m}-x^{\circ}\right|$, there is no loss of generality in assuming that the sequence $\left(x^{m}-x^{\circ}\right) / r_{m}$ is constant, with

values $z \in\left\{\left(-\frac{1}{2}, 0\right),\left(\frac{1}{2}, 0\right)\right\}$. Consider the blow-up sequence $v_{m}$ given in (7.25), and also the sequence

$$
u_{m}(x)=\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r_{m} x\right)}{r_{m}^{3 / 2}}
$$

Note that each $u_{m}$ is a subsonic variational solution of (3.4), and (7.33) shows that $v_{m}$ is a scalar multiple of $u_{m}$. Since $x^{m} \in \Sigma^{u}$, we have that $z \in \Sigma^{u_{m}}$. It follows from Lemma 7.6 (1) and (2) that for each $m$,

$$
D\left(z, u_{m} ; r\right) \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \quad \text { for all } r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)
$$

Thus, we obtain

$$
r \int_{B_{r}(z)} \frac{\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2}}{H\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)} d x \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \int_{\partial B_{r}(z)} \frac{u_{m}^{2}}{H_{0}} d S \quad \text { for all } r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)
$$

Thanks to the growth condition on $u$, we can deduce that $H\left(\left|\nabla u_{m}\right|^{2} ; x_{2}\right) \geqslant$ $H\left(x_{2} ; x_{2}\right)=H_{0}$, since $H(t ; s)$ is a non-decreasing function with respect to the first component. Since $v_{m}$ is a scalar multiple of $u_{m}$, we have

$$
r \int_{B_{r}(z)}\left|\nabla v_{m}\right|^{2} d x \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \int_{\partial B_{r}(z)} v_{m}^{2} d S \quad \text { for all } r \in\left(0, r_{0}\right)
$$

Proposition 7.13 implies that the sequence $v_{m}$ converges strongly to $v_{0}$ in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{r_{0} / 4}(z)\right)$, and hence

$$
r \int_{B_{r}(z)}\left|\nabla v_{0}\right|^{2} d x \geqslant \frac{3}{2} \int_{\partial B_{r}(z)} v_{0}^{2} d S \quad \text { for all } r \in\left(0, \frac{r_{0}}{4}\right)
$$

But recalling (7.39), we have by direct calculation that

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{r \int_{B_{r}(z)}\left|\nabla v_{0}\right|^{2} d x}{\int_{\partial B_{r}(z)} v_{0}^{2} d S}=1
$$

This yields a contradiction.

# 8. CONCLusions 

According to our analysis on the non-degenerate stagnation points (cf. § 6) and the degenerate stagnation points (in § 7). We are able to prove our main results.

Theorem 8.1. Let $n=2$, let $u$ be a subsonic weak solution of (3.4), and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { in } \Omega
$$

Then the set $S^{u}$ of stagnation points is a finite or countable set. Each accumulation point of $S^{u}$ is a point of the locally finite set $\Sigma^{u}$. At each point $x^{\circ}$ of $S^{u} \backslash \Sigma^{u}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}} & \rightarrow u_{0}(R, \theta) \\
& \equiv \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} R^{3 / 2} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2}\left(\min \left\{\max \left\{\theta, \frac{\pi}{6}\right\}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and locally uniformly on $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, where $x=$ $(R \cos \theta, R \sin \theta)$. Moreover,

$$
\mathcal{L}^{2}\left(B_{1} \cap\left(\left\{x: u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)>0\right\} \triangle\left\{x: \frac{\pi}{6}<\theta<\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}\right)\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, and, for each $\delta>0$,

$$
r^{-3 / 2} L u\left(\left(x^{\circ}+B_{r}\right) \backslash\left\{x: \min \left\{\left|\theta-\frac{\pi}{6}\right|,\left|\theta-\frac{5 \pi}{6}\right|\right\}<\delta\right\}\right) \rightarrow 0
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$. At each point $x^{\circ}$ of $\Sigma^{u}$ there exists an integer $N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \geqslant 2$ such that

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{\alpha}} \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { as } r \rightarrow 0^{+}
$$

strongly in $L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ for each $\alpha \in\left[0, N\left(x^{\circ}\right)\right)$, and

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{\sqrt{r^{-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{R_{0}} d S}} \rightarrow \frac{R^{N\left(x^{\circ}\right)}\left|\sin \left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \min \{\max \{\theta, 0\}, \pi\}\right)\right|}{\sqrt{\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1}{R_{0}} \sin ^{2}\left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \theta\right) d \theta}}
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(B_{1} \backslash\{0\}\right)$ and weakly in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$ where $x=$ $(R \cos \theta, R \sin \theta)$.

Proof. By Lemma 4.8, $u$ is a variational solution of (3.4) and satisfies

$$
r^{-3 / 2} \int_{B_{r}(y)} \sqrt{x_{2}}\left|\nabla \chi_{\{u>0\}}\right| d x \leqslant C_{0}
$$

for all $B_{r}(y) \subset \subset \Omega$ such that $y_{2}=0$.
It follows from Lemma 7.2, Proposition 5.5, Lemma 6.4, Lemma 7.6, Lemma 7.10, Theorem 7.14 and Theorem 7.15 that the set of stagnation points $S^{u}$ is a finite set or countable set with asymptotics as in the statement, and that the only possible accumulation points are elements of $\Sigma^{u}$.

Theorem 8.1 implies Theorem B immediately. When $\{u=0\}$ has locally finitely many connected components, we conclude the following result, which directly implies Theorem A.

Theorem 8.2. Let $n=2$, let $u$ be a subsonic weak solution of (3.4) and suppose that

$$
|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{+} \quad \text { in } \Omega
$$

Suppose moreover that $\{u=0\}$ has locally only finitely many connected components. Then the set $S^{u}$ of stagnation points is locally in $\Omega$ a finite set. At each stagnation point $x^{\circ}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}} \rightarrow & u_{0}(R, \theta) \\
& \equiv \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} R^{3 / 2} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2}\left(\min \left\{\max \left\{\theta, \frac{\pi}{6}\right\}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and locally uniformly on $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, where $x=$ $(R \cos \theta, R \sin \theta)$, and in an open neighborhood of $x^{\circ}$ the topological free boundary $\partial\{u>0\}$ is the union of two $C^{1}$-graphs with right and left tangents at $x^{\circ}$.

Proof. We first show that the set $\Sigma^{u}$ is empty. Suppose towards a contradiction that there exists $x^{\circ} \in \Sigma^{u}$. From Theorem 7.14 we infer that there exists an integer $N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \geqslant 2$ such that

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{\sqrt{r^{-1} \int_{\partial B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right)} \frac{u^{2}}{H_{0}} d S}} \rightarrow \frac{R^{N\left(x^{\circ}\right)}\left|\sin \left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \min \{\max \{\theta, 0\}, \pi\}\right)\right|}{\sqrt{\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{1}{H_{0}} \sin ^{2}\left(N\left(x^{\circ}\right) \theta\right) d \theta}}
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\text {loc }}^{1,2}\left(B_{1} \backslash\{0\}\right)$ and weakly in $W^{1,2}\left(B_{1}\right)$ where $x=$ $(R \cos \theta, R \sin \theta)$. But then the assumption on $\{u=0\}$ implies that $\partial_{\text {red }}\{u>$ $0\}$ contains the image of a continuous curve converging, as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, locally in $\left\{x_{2}>0\right\}$ to a half-line $\{\alpha z: \alpha>0\}$ where $z_{2}>0$. It follows that

$$
\mathcal{H}^{1}\left(\left\{x_{2}>\frac{1}{2}\right\} \cap \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\left\{x: u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)>0\right\}\right) \geqslant c_{1}>0
$$

where $\mathcal{H}^{1}$ denotes the 1-dimensional Hausdorff measure. This however contradicts to

$$
0 \leftarrow L \frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}}\left(B_{1}\right)=\int_{B_{1} \cap \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\left\{x: u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)>0\right\}} \sqrt{x_{2}} d S
$$

Hence $\Sigma^{u}$ is indeed empty.
Let $x^{\circ} \in S^{u}$, then Theorem 8.1 shows that

$$
\frac{u\left(x^{\circ}+r x\right)}{r^{3 / 2}} \rightarrow \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3} R^{3 / 2} \cos \left(\frac{3}{2}\left(\min \left\{\max \left\{\theta, \frac{\pi}{6}\right\}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}\right\}-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)
$$

as $r \rightarrow 0^{+}$, strongly in $W_{\text {loc }}^{1,2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}\right)$ and locally uniformly on $\mathbb{R}^{2}$, where $x=$ $(R \cos \theta, R \sin \theta)$. The last statement follows easily from the flatness-implies$C^{1, \alpha}$-regularity results in [3, Theorem 6.1].

Remark 8.3. The proof of Theorem C follows along a similar argument as in [61, Theorem 4.6], the only changes in the proof is that the convergence of measures (cf. Lemma 6.4) in our compressible case changes into

$$
L u_{m} \rightarrow \frac{\Delta u_{0}}{H_{0}} \quad \text { as } m \rightarrow+\infty
$$

We also note that the assumption (assuming that the free surface is a continuous injective curve) of Theorem C is stronger than both Theorem A and Theorem B. The advantage and the principal motivation for carrying it out in this way is that the singular asymptotics near the stagnation points become explicit under the injective curve assumption.

# Appendix A. Proof of Lemma 1.1 

It follows from the definition of $\rho_{\mathrm{cr}, x_{2}}$ that it is a continuous function with respect to $x_{2}$ up to $x_{2}=x_{2}^{\mathrm{st}}$, then

$$
\lim _{\substack{x \rightarrow x^{\circ} \\ x \in\{\psi>0\}}} \rho_{\mathrm{cr}, x_{2}}=\rho_{\mathrm{cr}, x_{2}^{\circ}}:=a
$$

On the other hand, since

$$
\lim _{\substack{x \rightarrow x^{\circ} \\ x \in\{\psi>0\}}} \rho(|\nabla \psi(x)|^{2} ; x_{2})=\bar{\rho}_{0}:=b
$$

since $\bar{\rho}_{0}>\rho_{\mathrm{cr}, x_{2}}$ for all $0<x_{2} \leqslant x_{2}^{\mathrm{st}}$, we have that $b>a$. Let us define $\varepsilon_{0}:=\frac{1}{2}(b-a)>0$. Then the above two limits give that $\left|\rho\left(|\nabla \psi|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)-b\right|<\varepsilon_{0}$ and $\left|\rho_{\mathrm{cr}, x_{2}}-a\right|<\varepsilon_{0}$ in $B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right) \cap\{\psi>0\}$ for some $r$, depending only on $x^{\circ}$. Thus,

$$
\rho\left(|\nabla \psi|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)>\frac{a+b}{2} \quad \text { in } B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right) \cap\{\psi>0\}
$$

and

$$
\rho_{\mathrm{cr}, x_{2}}<\frac{a+b}{2} \quad \text { in } B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right) \cap\{\psi>0\}
$$

Therefore

$$
\rho\left(|\nabla \psi|^{2} ; x_{2}\right)>\frac{a+b}{2}>\rho_{\mathrm{cr}, x_{2}} \quad \text { in } B_{r}\left(x^{\circ}\right) \cap\{\psi>0\}
$$

as desired.

## Appendix B. Proof of the first domain variation formula

The idea of the proof is inspired by [24, Sect.4]. Given a vector field $\phi \in C_{0}^{1}(\Omega)$, for small $\varepsilon>0$ we consider the ODE flow $y=y(\varepsilon ; x)$ defined by the Cauchy problem

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
y(0 ; x) & =x, \quad x \in \Omega \\
\partial_{\varepsilon} y(\varepsilon ; x) & =\phi(y(\varepsilon ; x))
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

We remark that, for small $\varepsilon \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
y(\varepsilon ; x)=x+\varepsilon \phi(y(\varepsilon ; x))+o(\varepsilon)=x+\varepsilon \phi(x)+o(\varepsilon)
$$

Accordingly,

$$
D_{x} y(\varepsilon ; x)=I+\varepsilon D \phi(y(\varepsilon ; x))+o(\varepsilon)=I+\varepsilon D \phi(x)+o(\varepsilon)
$$

where $I$ denotes the $n$-dimensional identity matrix. Also, the map $\mathbb{R}^{n} \ni$ $x \mapsto y(\varepsilon ; x)$ is invertible for small $\varepsilon$. In other words, we can consider the inverse diffeomorphism $x(\varepsilon ; y)$. In this way, we see that

$$
x(\varepsilon ; y(\varepsilon ; x))=x \quad \text { and } \quad y(\varepsilon ; x(\varepsilon ; y))=y
$$

We know from (B.1) that

$$
x(\varepsilon ; y)=y(\varepsilon ; x(\varepsilon ; y))-\varepsilon \phi(y(\varepsilon ; x(\varepsilon ; y)))+o(\varepsilon)=y-\varepsilon \phi(y)+o(\varepsilon)
$$

and therefore

$$
D_{y} x(\varepsilon ; y)=I-\varepsilon D \phi(y)+o(\varepsilon)
$$

and in particular,

$$
\operatorname{det} D_{y} x(\varepsilon ; y)=1-\varepsilon \operatorname{div} \phi(y)+o(\varepsilon)
$$

ow given $u$ we define $u_{\varepsilon}(x):=u(y(\varepsilon ; x))$, and we infer from (B.2) that

$$
\nabla u_{\varepsilon}(x)=\nabla u(y(\varepsilon ; x))+\varepsilon D \phi(y(\varepsilon ; x)) \cdot \nabla u(y(\varepsilon ; x))+o(\varepsilon)
$$

Define $\Omega_{\varepsilon}:=y(\varepsilon ; \Omega)$. Since $y(\varepsilon ; x)=x$ for any $x \in \Omega^{c}$, we have that $y(\varepsilon ; \Omega)=\Omega$. Moreover, (B.3) implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\nabla u_{\varepsilon}(x)\right|^{2} & =|\nabla u(y(\varepsilon ; x))|^{2} \\
& +2 \varepsilon \nabla u(y(\varepsilon ; x)) D \phi(y(\varepsilon ; x)) \cdot \nabla u(y(\varepsilon ; x))+o(\varepsilon)
\end{aligned}
$$

Changing the variable $y=y(\varepsilon ; x)$, we see

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\Omega} F\left(\left|\nabla u_{\varepsilon}(x)\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) d x \\
& =\int_{\Omega} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2}+2 \varepsilon \nabla u D \phi \nabla u+o(\varepsilon)\right. \\
& \left.\quad y_{n}-\varepsilon \phi_{n}+o(\varepsilon)\right) \mid \operatorname{det} D_{y} x(\varepsilon ; y) \mid d y \\
& =\int_{\Omega} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2}+2 \varepsilon \nabla u D \phi \nabla u+o(\varepsilon)\right. \\
& \left.\quad y_{n}-\varepsilon \phi_{n}+o(\varepsilon)\right)(1-\varepsilon \operatorname{div} \phi+o(\varepsilon)) d y
\end{aligned}
$$

A direct calculation gives that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& F\left(|\nabla u|^{2}+2 \varepsilon \nabla u D \phi \nabla u(y) ; y_{n}-\varepsilon \phi_{n}\right) \\
& =F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; y_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +2 \varepsilon \partial_{1} F\left(|\nabla u(y)|^{2} ; y_{n}-\varepsilon \phi_{n}(y)\right) \nabla u(y) D \phi(y) \nabla u(y) \\
& -\varepsilon \partial_{2} F\left(|\nabla u(y)|^{2}+2 \varepsilon \nabla u(y) D \phi(y) \nabla u(y)\right) \phi_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\Omega} F\left(\left|\nabla u_{\varepsilon}\right|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) d x-\int_{\Omega} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) d x \\
& =2 \varepsilon \int_{\Omega} \partial_{1} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}-\varepsilon \phi_{n}+o(\varepsilon)\right) \nabla u D \phi \nabla u d x \\
& -\varepsilon \int_{\Omega} \partial_{2} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2}+2 \varepsilon \nabla u D \phi \nabla u+o(\varepsilon) ; x_{n}\right) \phi_{n} d x \\
& -\varepsilon \int_{\Omega} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \operatorname{div} \phi_{n} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, one can show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\Omega} \lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\left\{u_{\varepsilon}>0\right\}}(x) d x-\int_{\Omega} \lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}}(x) d x \\
& =-\varepsilon \int_{\Omega} \lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \phi_{n}(x) \chi_{\{u>0\}}(x) d x \\
& -\varepsilon \int_{\Omega} \lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \operatorname{div} \phi(x) \chi_{\{u>0\}}(x) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to the definition of first variation, we can deduce from (B.4) and (B.5) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =-\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} \frac{J_{F}\left(u_{\varepsilon}(x) ; \Omega\right)-J_{F}(u(x) ; \Omega)}{\varepsilon} \\
& =\int_{\Omega}\left(F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}}\right) \operatorname{div} \phi_{n} d x \\
& -2 \int_{\Omega} \partial_{1} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \nabla u D \phi \nabla u d x \\
& +\int_{\Omega}\left(\lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}}+\partial_{2} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)\right) \phi_{n} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, a direct calculation gives that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{div}\left(F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \phi\right) \\
& =F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \operatorname{div} \phi+2 \frac{\phi \cdot\left(D^{2} u \nabla u\right)}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}+\partial_{2} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \phi_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the fact $\partial_{1} F=H$. We also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{div}\left(\partial_{1} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)(\phi \cdot \nabla u) \nabla u\right) \\
& =\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla u}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right)(\phi \cdot \nabla u)+\frac{\nabla u D \phi \nabla u}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}+\frac{\phi \cdot\left(D^{2} u \nabla u\right)}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\operatorname{div}\left(\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \phi\right)=\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \operatorname{div} \phi+\lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \phi_{n}
$$

Thus, we can show that Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{div}\left(\left(F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right)\right) \phi\right)-2 \operatorname{div}\left(\partial_{1} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)(\phi \cdot \nabla u) \nabla u\right) \\
& =\left(F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right)\right) \operatorname{div} \phi-2 \frac{\nabla u D \phi \nabla u}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)} \\
& +\operatorname{div}\left(\frac{\nabla u}{H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)}\right)(\phi \cdot \nabla u)+\partial_{2} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right) \phi_{n}+\lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \phi_{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Integrating this equality in $\Omega \cap\{u>0\}$, and (4.4) follows immediately from the definition of subsonic variational solution and the fact that $\nu=-\frac{\nabla u}{|\nabla u|}$ on $\Omega \cap \partial\{u>0\}$.

# Appendix C. Proof of Lemma 4.8 

The proof follows a similar argument as in [64, Theorem 5.1] and [60, Lemma 3.4]. For any $\phi \in C_{0}^{1}\left(\Omega \cap\left\{x_{n}>\tau\right\} ; \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and a small positive $\delta$ we find a covering

$$
\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right) \supset \operatorname{supp} \phi \cap(\partial\{u>0\} \backslash \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\{u>0\})
$$

satisfying $\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} r_{i}^{n-1} \leqslant \delta$. Given that $\operatorname{supp} \phi \cap(\partial\{u>0\} \backslash \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\{u>0\})$ is a compact set, one may reduce the covering to a finite sub-covering

$$
\bigcup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right) \supset \operatorname{supp} \phi \cap(\partial\{u>0\} \backslash \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\{u>0\})
$$

satisfying $\sum_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} r_{i}^{n-1} \leqslant \delta$. Since $u$ is a subsonic weak solution, we know that

$$
u \in C^{1}(\overline{\{u>0\}} \cap\left(\operatorname{supp} \phi \backslash \cup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right)\right))
$$

and $u$ satisfies the transmission condition

$$
|\nabla u|^{2}=x_{n} \quad \text { on } \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\{u>0\} \cap\left(\operatorname{supp} \phi \backslash \cup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right)\right)
$$

Denoting $F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)$ by $F, \partial_{1} F\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)$ by $\partial_{1} F$, and $H\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)$ by $H$ for the sake of notations. Integrating by parts in $\{u>0\} \backslash \cup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right)$ we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\Omega}\left(F \operatorname{div} \phi\right. & \left.2 \partial_{1} F \nabla u D \phi \nabla u+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \operatorname{div} \phi\right) \\
& \left.+\int_{\Omega} \lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \phi_{n}+\partial_{2} F \phi_{n}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leqslant \mid \int_{\cup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right)}\left(F \operatorname{div} \phi-2 \partial_{1} F \nabla u D \phi \nabla u+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \operatorname{div} \phi d x\right. \\
& \left.+\int_{\cup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right)} \lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \phi_{n}\right) d x \mid \\
& +\mid \int_{\{u>0\} \cap \partial\left(\cup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right)\right)}\left(F \phi \cdot \nu-2 \partial_{1} F \nabla u \cdot \nu \nabla u \cdot \phi+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \phi \cdot \nu\right) d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \mid \\
& +\mid \int_{\partial\{u>0\} \backslash \cup_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} B_{r_{i}}\left(x^{i}\right)}\left(\lambda\left(x_{n}\right)-\Lambda\left(|\nabla u|^{2} ; x_{n}\right)\right) \phi \cdot \nu d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \mid \\
& \leqslant \mathscr{C}_{1} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} r_{i}^{n}+\mathscr{C}_{2} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{\delta}} r_{i}^{n-1},
\end{aligned}
$$

and passing to the limit as $\delta \rightarrow 0$, we obtain that $u$ is a variational solution of (3.1) in the set $\Omega \cap\left\{x_{n}>\tau\right\}$. Let us now take $\phi \in C_{0}^{1}\left(\Omega ; \mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and $\eta:=\min \left\{1, x_{n} / \tau\right\}$, plug in the product $\eta \phi$ into the already observed result, and use the growth assumption $|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant C x_{n}^{+}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
0= & \int_{\Omega} \eta\left(F \operatorname{div} \phi-2 \partial_{1} F \nabla u D \phi \nabla u+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \operatorname{div} \phi\right. \\
& \left.+\int_{\Omega} \lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \phi_{n}+\partial_{2} F \phi_{n}\right) d x \\
+ & \frac{1}{\tau} \int_{\Omega \cap\left\{0<x_{n}<\tau\right\}} \phi \cdot\left(F e_{n}-2 \partial_{1} F \nabla u \cdot e_{n} \nabla u+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} e_{n}+\partial_{2} F e_{n}\right) d x \\
= & o(1)+\int_{\Omega}\left(F \operatorname{div} \phi-2 H \nabla u D \phi \nabla u+\lambda\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \operatorname{div} \phi\right. \\
& \left.+\int_{\Omega} \lambda^{\prime}\left(x_{n}\right) \chi_{\{u>0\}} \phi_{n}+\partial_{2} F \phi_{n}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\tau \rightarrow 0$. Last, let us prove $r^{1 / 2-n} \int_{B_{r}(y)} \sqrt{x_{n}}\left|\nabla \chi_{\{u>0\}}\right| d x \leqslant C_{0}$ for all $B_{r}(y) \subset \subset \Omega$ such that $y_{n}=0$. Let us consider for such $y$ the rescaled function $u_{r}(x)=\frac{u(y+r x)}{r^{3 / 2}}$. Using the assumption $|\nabla u|^{2} \leqslant C x_{n}^{+}$locally in $\Omega$ and the weak solution property that the topological free boundary $\partial\{u>$ $0\} \cap \Omega \cap\left\{x_{n}>\tau\right\}$ is locally a $C^{2, \alpha}$ surface, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =\int_{\partial B_{1} \cap\left\{u_{r}>0\right\}} \frac{\nabla u_{r} \cdot x}{H\left(r\left|\nabla u_{r}\right|^{2} ; r y_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& -\int_{B_{1} \cap \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\{u>0\}} \frac{\nabla u_{r} \cdot x}{H\left(r\left|\nabla u_{r}\right|^{2} ; r y_{n}\right)} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leqslant \mathscr{C} \int_{\partial B_{1} \cap\left\{u_{r}>0\right\}}\left|\nabla u_{r}\right| d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}-e \int_{B_{1} \cap \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\left\{u_{r}>0\right\}}\left|\nabla u_{r}\right| d \mathcal{H}^{n-1} \\
& \leqslant \mathscr{C}-e r^{1 / 2-n} \int_{B_{r}(y) \cap \partial_{\operatorname{red}}\{u>0\}} \sqrt{x_{n}} d \mathcal{H}^{n-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

as required. Here we used the fact $e \leqslant H\left(r\left|\nabla u_{r}\right|^{2} ; r y_{n}\right) \leqslant \mathscr{C}$ in the third inequality and $\left|\nabla u_{r}\right| \leqslant C$ in the last inequality.

abstract:
In 1880, Stokes examined an incompressible irrotational periodic traveling
water wave under the influence of gravity and conjectured the existence of an
extreme wave with a corner of $120^{\circ}$ at the crest. The first rigorous
proof of the conjecture was given by Amick, Fraenkel and Toland, as well as by
Plotnikov independently via the Nekrasov integral equation. In the early 2010s,
Weiss and Varvarucva revisited the conjecture by applying a new geometric
method, which provided an affirmative answer to the conjecture without
requiring structural assumptions such as the isolation of the stagnation
points, the symmetry and the monotonicity of the free surface that were
necessary in the previous works.
  The main purpose of this paper is to establish the validity of the Stokes
conjecture in the context of compressible gravity water waves. More precisely,
we prove that a sharp crest forms near each stagnation point of a compressible
gravity water wave with an included angle of $120^{\circ}$, which gives a first
proof to the compressible counterpart of the classical conjecture by Stokes in
1880.
  The central aspect of our approach is the discovery of a new monotonicity
formula for quasilinear free boundary problems of the Bernoulli-type. Another
observation is the introduction of a new nonlinear frequency formula, along
with a compensated compactness argument for the compressible Euler system. The
developed monotonicity formula enables us to do blow-up analysis at each
stagnation point and helps us obtain the singular profile of the free surface
near each stagnation points. The degenerate stagnation points can be further
analyzed with the help of the compensated compactness argument using the
frequency formula.
